http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value:
Places are the individual nodes of our cable networks. They are either tagged by this page, or one of the following place designations: Place 0-299, Place 300-599, Place 600-899, Place 900-1199, Place 1200-1499, and Place 1500-1799.
To create a page for a new cable, see the reference page for places.

In the nineteenth century, Guam was under Spanish rule. Sumay emerged a small port village on the island's Apra harbor, a favorite anchoring spot for fishermen and whalers. In 1898, the Americans sailed into the harbor, and took the island with no struggle. Sumay subsequently became a node for circulations through Guam. The United States set up a Marine Corps Aircraft Squadron. Pan American Airways used the area as a landing for its China Clipper, and subsequently built the first hotel on Guam there. The Commercial Pacific Cable Company established their cable station there. These businesses played a large role in the economic prosperity and development of the village, and many villagers worked at the station.
This cable was extended between Guam and Japan's Bonin Islands in 1906. It connected the Commercial Pacific Cable's line from the United States all the way to Asia.

Strung between Hawai'i and California in 1902, and extending onward to Guam, Japan, and the Philippines in the years after, the Commercial Pacific Cable was the first "American" transpacific link. Secretly, however, it was owned in part by the British Eastern Telegraph company, a trade off the cable layers had to give up in order to gain access to lucrative Chinese markets.

About four hours by plane from Tokyo, Manila, and Seoul, five hours from Taipei and Hong Kong, and seven hours from Honolulu (with direct flights from all of these cities), Guam is a point of interconnection between East Asian and American transportation routes. I arrive on the flight from Hawai‘i at A.B. Won Pat International Airport on a hot summer afternoon, where I am met by a distant relative, the son of my mother’s brother’s wife’s cousin (everyone seems to have a distant connection to Guam). While guiding me on a tour of Tumon Bay, a waterfront lined with towering, extravagant hotels, upscale designer stores, and seedy strip clubs, he asks me what brings me to the island since “it’s not on the way anywhere.” 

As I describe the cable networks that position Guam as a center for Pacific Internet traffic, I think about how this island – home to approximately 180,000 residents – is actually on the way to a number of places. It is a temporary destination for Japanese and Korean tourists, Micronesian islanders looking for an education or a job, Americans stopping for a tour on one of the two military bases, and travelers on a layover between cities. Guam is a meeting point, a site of exchange at which different kinds of flows do not simply terminate, but are interconnected.

Bamfield was a critical gateway during the telegraph era, a site where international signals punctured Canada and threaded it to other territories around the world. Yet this station was considered one of the most remote places in the Pacific Cable Board’s network due to the difficulties of regional transport. The nearby inlet was known as the “graveyard of the Pacific” for its numerous wrecks; the coastal Telegraph Trail served as a lifeline for their survivors. One cableman recollects that even though it was only one hundred and twenty miles to Victoria, the largest city on Vancouver Island, “you might as well have been a thousand miles away for all the difficulties in transportation.” The town had no road access until 1963 and in order to visit, you have to drive hours along narrow gravel logging roads, avoiding trucks that barrel down without warning and stir up clouds of dust in their wake. Arriving in the small town, which consists of a motel, a bar, and a handful of stores, you see young people strolling along the streets, divers suiting up, and trucks fitted out for recreational camping. Bamfield would not be a destination for so many visitors if it were not for the establishment of a marine science center, which transformed the abandoned cable station into labs and classrooms.

Sanford Fleming and the Canadian Government mobilized arguments about security to establish the first transpacific cable system in 1902, creating a foundational route for all north-south Pacific traffic. This system mastered the scale of the globe: the Pacific Cable Board line between Bamfield, Canada and Fanning Island was then the longest undersea cable in the world. This system also required new expenditures for infrastructure and planning. A new 8,000 ton ship, the Colonia, had to be constructed specifically for the line.

In the 1920s, the Pacific Cable Board lay a higher capacity system, a "loaded cable" that eventually transmitted 150 words/minute directly from Suva, Fiji to Auckland, bypassing Norfolk Island. Thus began the era in the South Pacific of skipping over intermediate islands to ensure more "direct" routing.

The first transpacific cable terminated in Southport, Australia, a small beach town south of Brisbane. In 1901, prior to the cable's arrival, the town's population was a mere 1230 people. From Southport, traffic was then routed by land to Sydney, but this terrestrial connection was one of the least stable segments of the entire transpacific cable. Aboriginal inhabitants regularly cut down the line. Despite the fickle land-line, this cable station operated for sixty years, closing in July 1962. Even after it stopped transmitting international messages, the cable station continued to have a legacy in the beach town. In the 1980s, when the buildings were under threat of demolition, residents spearheaded a campaign to save them, and the cable station was renovated, restored, and moved to become the Music Department of the nearby Southport School. Today a ark, a street, and an apartment building have all been named after the area's former transpacific cable.
The Pacific Cable Board's landline between Southport and Sydney was so unreliable that, when the system was upgraded in 1923, it was replaced by a submarine cable.

You land on a beach on the Central California coast. You're in between two of the first nodes for internet traffic, Stanford University and the University of California Santa Barbara, and two hundred miles from the major internet technology hub in Silicon Valley. This is where the Internet enters the United States via undersea cable.

The landscape is anything but technological. Behind you, an expansive state park wraps around the California coast. It is cold and rainy. Fog covers the ocean, but it deters neither surfers nor the signals transiting invisibly beneath the beach. From here, signals extend outward to Hawai'i, Guam, Japan, and onward to much of Asia. In what direction will you go?

The Japan-U.S. cable network was one of several ring networks laid at the turn of the twenty-first century. It cost over a billion dollars and has connected three landing sites in Japan with two U.S. stations via a direct northern route and a southern route through Hawaii. Owned by a 35-member consortium, the cable has been upgraded to transmit more than 15 times its original capacity.

The Southern Cross Cable Network was designed as an Internet-based cable that, at the time, would be the fastest and most straightforward route from Australia and New Zealand to the United States. Just as Southern Cross was being put in the water, the cable market collapsed – this was brought on by a combination of the excess capacity offered by the numerous cable systems laid in the late 1990s. The timing of Southern Cross was “perfect,” as its builders recollect, poised on the crest of the cable boom: if they'd started a little bit later, it likely wouldn't have happened.

Central California has been a cable hub since 1964, when a telephone cable to Hawai'i was routed through Morro Bay. The first station in the area was constructed by AT&T, and its location midway between San Francisco and Los Angeles placed it out of the way of potential nuclear attack. Although the state has been a hub in communication technology, it has also played an important role in the growth of the environmental movement, pioneered breakthroughs in environmental policy, and is committed to the preservation of wilderness areas. Daniel Press articulates the apparent contradiction: “at the vanguard of paradoxical trends, California is one of the fastest growing states in the country, but is the most ambivalent about change.” Today there are increasing conflicts between these two forces.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: The third link between Hawai'i and the United States was a straightforward engineering project. AT&T needed more transpacific capacity, and as in their previous systems, collaborated with Hawaiian Telecom to build the infrastructure that would meet their needs. As a result, the two companies would then own all of the circuits on the system, blocking out any other telecommunications companies from ownership.
Hawaii-5 was AT&T's second fiber-optic cable between California and Hawai'i, yet like their first fiber-optic link, the line was economically obsolete in only twelve years.

The Hawai'i-2 telephone cable was the second link between the United States mainland and Hawai'i. Extended in 1964, it connected to a transpacific link that shuttled signals onward to Japan. For the system, a new station was constructed on O'ahu's west shore, which would become a critical hub for internet signals half a century later.

Trans-Pacific Cable 5 was one of the first ring systems in the Pacific. It has two branches between Japan and the U.S., a direct northern route and a southern crossing via Hawaii and Guam, where it interconnects with other global networks. More than 70 telecom companies from over 40 countries were involved in its construction, and two-thirds of its capacity was reserved before it entered service in the mid-1990s. TPC-5’s southern line carried high-definition television broadcasts for the 1996 Summer Olympic Games in Atlanta.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: Bondi Beach is perhaps better known as a world famous surfing locale than as a hotspot for cable landing. Since the early twentieth century, however, Bondi has been the landing point for numerous telegraph, telephone, and fiber-optic cable systems. Located right near the center of Sydney, Bondi offers proximity for cable layers that seek to move in close to downtown markets. The most difficult part for cable companies is getting from the coastal beaches where cables land to Sydney's central cable station. Given the lack of duct space under the streets, this makes it difficult to lay new systems directly into major cities.

The Pacific Cable Board cable was laid in 1902. It had been imagined for decades before it could actually be laid. It was only once the British came to value strategic communications that Sanford Fleming, a Canadian, was able to push the project through.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: Tasman 1 was the second telephone cable laid across the Tasman sea, establishing 640 new circuits between Australia and New Zealand. A state sponsored affair, it was a collaboration of the Australia Overseas Telecommunications Commission and the New Zealand Post Office, and was manufactured by the British company Standard Telephone and Cables Limited. It cost 14.3 million.
In 1917, the 1890 cable across the Tasman Sea was diverted to Titahi Bay In New Zealand and to Bondi Beach in Australia.
Eastern Extension's cables between Australia and New Zealand were relocated to Bondi Beach and Titahi Bay, outside of Wellington, in 1917.
In 1932, the shore end of the cable was moved north from Wellington to Muriwai Beach, outside of Auckland. As New Zealand's commercial traffic moved northward, so did the cables.
The expansive Commonwealth Pacific Cable, which stretched across the Pacific from Hawai'i to New Zealand and Australia, was officially opened in 1963.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: At the turn of the twenty-first century, three cables came ashore on the rural coast of western Oregon. While systems of the coaxial period usually terminated close to shore, these lines wind inland for over seventy miles, through the fir-populated mountains of the Tillamook State Forest to a Portland suburb nestled in the heart of “Silicon Forest.” The area was first granted this nickname in 1981, only a few years after Intel established a research campus there. Yet the seeds of Silicon Forest were planted much earlier. In the 1930s, the U.S. Forest Service Radio Lab was created in Portland, and developed wireless technologies to track fires as they spread through the forest, including the one that now borders the cable route. Engineers at the Radio Lab eventually developed two of Portland’s most well-known technology companies, setting the stage for today’s high-tech boom. Hillsboro, Oregon is now the home to many computer researchers, chip manufacturers, and cable stations, as well as a budding hub of data center activity. Companies are drawn to Silicon Forest because of its “welcoming” environment: not only do companies get massive tax breaks they in Hillsboro’s E-Commerce zone, but they have immediate access to cheap hydroelectric power from the nearby Columbia River.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: Hong Kong was one of the telegraph hubs of the British Empire and a key entry point into China. The first undersea link connected the island in 1871, and in the years that followed, cables extended outward from the island to Shanghai, Manila, and other locations in the Pacific. From their landing at Telegraph Bay, named for the cables, they connected inland to the busy Eastern Extension office. Today the landing site is the location of the Cyberport, a "creative digital community" built to foster information technology development in light of the expanding internet.

Los Angeles is the only truly urban cable landing on the United States’ west coast. Although it is difficult to string systems into densely populated areas, the more pressing reason for rural cable stations is a legacy of the Cold War. AT&T set up cable stations far from cities in the 1950s and 60s, away from potential targets of nuclear attack. As long as AT&T remained in control, cables stayed at remote stations. But in the 1990s, after the company was broken up, new players in the cable business set up new landings, including this one in the affluent seaside town of Hermosa Beach. From here, cables wind twenty miles inland to a “carrier hotel,” One Wilshire, where it links to hundreds of other networks. One Wilshire, like the cable landing, was also established as a competitor to AT&T. Set up by MCI and Sprint, it was located just three blocks down the road from AT&T’s major switching center. Today it is  one of the country’s most important telecommunications hubs. As Wired Magazine reported, if this building went down “most of California and parts of the rest of the world would not be able to connect to the internet.”

Launched in 2010, the Unity cable was the first in nearly ten years to link the U.S. and Japan under the Pacific. As such, it increased capacity along this route by nearly twenty percent. A six-company consortium that includes Google owns the cable, with the Pacnet portion branded as EAC Pacific .

You come ashore via a British cable, laid in 1902 to connect colonial holdings across the Pacific. This link brought with it not only colonial commands, but external business investment, especially in Fiji's growing agriculture industry. Such development made Fiji a well-liked hub by transiting cable men, who wrote about the station's short working hours, annual balls held by local sports clubs, and picnic trips up the river. By the mid-twentieth century, Fiji was a hub for the South Pacific, the only island with redundant routes both to the north and south. Fiji not only depended on these signal flows, but major Western powers depended on the cablemen's smooth operation.

In the 1920s, the Pacific Cable Board lay a higher capacity system directly from Suva, Fiji to Auckland, bypassing Norfolk Island. Thus began the era in the South Pacific of skipping over intermediate islands to ensure more "direct" routing.

In 1962, the balance of undersea cable power was shifting from British companies to the United States. The Keawa‘ula cable station had just been built on O‘ahu’s west shore to land the Commonwealth Pacific Cable. British transoceanic lines no longer stopped at Fanning Island, but rely on the United States. As such, its construction followed U.S. military specifications: it was located underground in a nuclear fallout shelter with walls that were feet thick. Arriving at this station today, you see an elegant set of steps up leading up to a front wall comprised of square glass blocks. One transmission engineer describesKeawa‘ula as a “palace.” Designed by a local Honolulu-based firm, the station's aboveground expansion was inspired by a visit from the CEO of Teleglobe Canada in the 1980s. With little space for gathering inside, the staff members at the time held their meeting in a small and cramped lunch room. Afterward, the CEO saw the station workers outside, joking around and hanging out in the trees like monkeys. In part inspired by the cable community, Teleglobe built a new, staff-friendly environment. The re-designed station grounded the communication hub in the heart of the cable family, yet left intact its Cold War foundations.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: In the 1950s, the first transpacific telephone cable was landed at Hanauma Bay, solidifying Hawai‘i’s as a hub of Pacific communications. The station was buried underground like many Cold War-era infrastructures, disguised as part of the hillside to prevent it from attack. The burying of the station was not its only impact on the environment: installers had to dynamite their way through a reef to ensure the cable had a safe path out to sea. More than fifty years later, this path has become a corridor of environmental tourism. The hole in the reef, now dubbed the “Telephone Cable Channel,” draws scuba divers and snorkelers through one of Hawai‘i’s foremost nature preserves. The cable, once used to traffic telephone calls, has been re-purposed by marine scientists to monitor the undersea environment, sensing aquatic lifeforms and seismic movements of the ocean floor.
The Hawai'i-2 cable was a short link that connected the HAW-1 cable that landed at Hanauma Bay to the transpacific link that came ashore at Makaha. Laid in 1964, it held only 128 telephone circuits.

Hawaii-1 was the first telephone cable that stretched across the Pacific, linking up California with O'ahu. After 32 years of service it was retired, and it has since been re-purposed for scientific research.

To get to California’s oldest still operational cable landing point, established in Point Arena in 1957, you would have to travel over a hundred miles north from San Francisco on narrow wooded roads. The cable station is positioned on a bluff overlooking the Pacific. Across the road from the station, families picnic at a campsite. Cows graze in a nearby pasture. Between the station and the beach, a sign restricts access to a “sensitive habitat area.” At first glance these environments, and the signs indicating environmental preservation, appear to secure both wildlife and cables, protecting infrastructure from perception and potential tampering. But such environments also pose a problem to those laying undersea cables. At this station, cable builders had to undergo extra permitting,  and ultimately delay, to ensure that they did not endanger the Point Arena mountain beaver.

One of the first fiber cable systems laid in the Pacific, Hawaii-4 was also one of the shortest lived. It went out of service after a mere 15 years, not because it broke, but rather due to economic obsolescence.

Banyuwangi means "Fragrant Water" in Javanese. Landing on its shores in the late nineteenth century, you emerge from vibrant blue waves. A gateway between Asia and Australia, this Dutch colony is a key stopping point for telegraph cables. In 1871 a link to Darwin was landed here, connecting Australia to the rest of the world through Java’s shores. While more a century in the future, surfers will travel from around the world to ride Banyuwangi’s waves, nineteenth-century cablemen complain that its waters were “uninviting” because of the “ever-present danger of crocodiles and sharks.” Here the cable intersects both turbulent waters and an ancient spiritual history. From the sixteenth to eighteenth century, the city was the capital of the Hindi Kingdom of Blambangan, which controlled the eastern tip of Java before it was taken over by the Dutch. To dig a trench for the telegraph cable to Singapore, native convicts were employed as laborers. But when they unearthed a Hindu Temple from 700 AD, the laborers refused to continue and women, who reportedly were unaffected by the native “superstitions,” had to be called in to complete the job.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: This was the first submarine telegraph line to Australia, laid by the British Australian Telegraph Company in 1871. Here it connected to the Overland Telegraph, which stretched almost 2,000 miles south to Adelaide. Although the undersea cable reached Darwin before the terrestrial link, it was severed in the ocean only shortly thereafter. Finally, after the submarine cable was repaired, Australia was enfolded into the British colonial network.

In September 1901, the Dutch East Indies government constructed a cable between Banjarmasin and Java as part of a new Dutch-German agreement “for the purpose of establishing telegraphic communication with their Colonial possessions in Asia.”

Typhoons and loneliness were the greatest perils for the cablemen working on the Cocos Islands in the early and middle twentieth century. Like Midway Island, the Cocos were largely uninhabited before the establishment of a cable station in 1901. The station was built at the highest point on the island: two meters above the high water mark, but this didn't keep it from damage during cyclones in 1907, 1911, and 1933. These caused flooding, collapsed palm trees onto the cable station houses, and wreaked havoc for international communications. During quieter moments, cablemen played tennis, worked, and waited eagerly for the arrival of supply ships every three months to bring food, mail, and mild excitement. Today, tourists seek out the Cocos for their quietude and isolation, sparsely and silently scattering themselves across the white beaches and blue-green waters. Floating just above the ocean’s surface, these low-lying islands still hold tropical forests, surrounded by soft beaches. There are no hills or mountains on the Cocos, and pools of fresh water collect here and there in the soil when it rains. True to their name, the islands’ sole export is coconuts, which hang heavily from palm trees everywhere you look.

Although it was originally a swampy wetland, Ancol is now something like the Disneyworld of Indonesia, bustling with rides, beach-goers, and children. Perched on the northern edge of East Java, in Jakarta Bay, it lies in between the upscale waterfront neighborhood of Pantai Mutiara and a busy international ferry terminal. The spot draws visitors from Jakarta and nearby Javanese cities, as well as many who cross the Java and South China Seas, coming to vacation from Sumatra, Singapore, or the Philippines. Cables have trafficked signals into the area since 1859, when an undersea cable connected from a neighborhood just south of Ancol to Singapore and the rest of Asia.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: A trading post since the second century, the island of Singapore was a hub of exchange for Southeast Asia long before the British settled there in 1819. When the first underwater telegraph cable arrived forty years later, Singapore was a bustling port city, what one nineteenth-century cable survey called “that thriving halfway house between Europe and the East.” Although produced in a factory in London more than six thousand miles away, the Singapore-Muntok cable was insulated with the coagulated sap of trees native to the region. The Malays had used this substance, known as gutta-percha, for generations to make whips and other products. In the 1840s, a Scottish doctor stationed in Singapore took notice of the sap and brought it back to London. Gutta-percha made an ideal electrical insulator and became the material of choice in the cable industry.  By the time gutta-percha-encased wires populated Singapore's waters, demand had all but wiped out the local flora that made its transmissions possible.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: An 1894 article about the cable in The Singapore Free Press and Mercantile Advertiser observes that this system, a duplicate route between Singapore and Hong Kong, "is a work almost of supererogation, certainly one not required or justified by the existing traffic." At the point a single cable could still carry all of the traffic to and from China. Instead, the aim was "to give greater assurance and security to communication between India and Europe and between [Singapore] and China." By connecting the main Naval base at Hong Kong with the other colonies (and stopping only on British territory, they predicting that the new cable would "materially increase the security of British interests in the Far East."
Laid by the Dutch East Indies Government in 1859, this cable was intended to help connect the Dutch colonies in the region.
This cable, manufactured by Telcon and laid by the China Submarine Telegraph Company, was completed on June 11, 1871.

“Imagine yourself in a black room, with most of the light and air cut off by screens, and blinds, a mirror lamp burning close to you, and a temperature of about 95 in the shade,” recounts one cable worker of his time in Darwin. Conditions were rough for the early operators at Australia’s first undersea telegraph station, which hooked the continent into the colonial network in 1871. In the summer the temperature was often over 100 degrees Fahrenheit, even despite the Hindu and Aboriginal servants employed to “waft away the heat.” The quarters of the telegraph men frequently flooded and stores often ran out of rations. When the cable was first landed, the men’s quarters had not even built, and for two years they lived in tents. During this time the terrestrial cable, linking Darwin to Adelaide, went out frequently, cut by Aborigines across the continent. Even despite the hardships, the cablemen were still a privileged lot in this colonial outpost. Their rooms, once built, were “lofty,” and their station was eventually furnished with amenities like a piano and billard table. “Perhaps the the greatest luxury they can boast of,” one reported, “is plenty of water gratis, for which others have to pay ninepence per bucket.”

Madang is fairly small as far as cities go – about 30,000 people live here – but it is the capital and most populous part of its province. The city’s infrastructure is focused outward rather than inward. It is home to many of Papua New Guinea’s export industries, and the landing point for an international fiber-optic cable. The main occupation for many here is a large timber industry, which logs the nearby Gogol forest. In addition, the city exports copra, coconuts, coffee, cocoa, and tobacco, and is home to tuna processing plants and engineering and joinery workshops. The people are also a mix – tourists, missionaries, and contract workers from countries around the world mingle with indigenous people speaking hundreds of different local languages. Papua New Guinea is considered one of the most culturally diverse places in the world, with over 800 different languages spoken by people living mainly in traditional tribal societies. Only a small percentage live in urban, modernized centers like Madang and Port Moresby. But even cities within the country have trouble interacting with each other: the volcanoes that run through the middle of the island have prevented any roads from being built between them.
<!--EndFragment-->

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: The South-East Asia Communications system terminated in Cairns, Australia, where it was linked via a microwave link to Sydney. But as one engineer recalls, this last wireless segment “was nothing but trouble. The cable would often just continually fail. Not because of the cable system, but the backhaul link between Cairns and Sydney.”

http://purl.org/dc/terms/rightsHolder.value: Pipe Networks

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: On the northwestern edge of Australia, Cairns gazes out across a serene blue-green sea. These peaceful waters are deceptive – underneath the surface there are mud flats, and farther out to sea, the Great Barrier Reef. The muddy, shallow bottom of the ocean means that Cairns is not the beach town it would seem destined to be. It caters primarily to tourists who stop by on their way to the reef, the area’s main attraction, which draws in flows of visitors every year, many of whom rely on the area's communications networks. In 1967, Cairns received its first cable, a link to Papua New Guinea, extending onward to Guam and Hong Kong. Nine years later, a second link was set up between Cairns and Papua New Guinea. The city remained a sort of branch outpost for Australia, a landing point for cables on the country's northern coast, until APNG was withdrawn from service in 1996. While its location at the tip of Australia makes it a natural outlet to Asia, the inland cable that connected these networks to Sydney has often caused problems, and the Great Barrier Reef, challenging to cross using cables, makes it difficult to bring signals in and out from abroad.

The Australia-Papua New Guinea cable was laid between Port Moresby and Cairns in 1975, becoming operational in 1976. The cable, like many others of this generation, outlasted its design life, serving Papua New Guinea until it was replaced by APNG-2 in 2006.

This northern suburb of Auckland, New Zealand, has been an outlet for northward communications for more than a century. In 1912, after a new Chief Post Office was opened in central Auckland, the Pacific Cable Board re-directed their cable from rural Doubtless Bay to Takapuna Beach. The workers from the station came with the cable, and the cable station was set up on in the Post Office, consolidating networks formerly distributed across the land. As the cable continued to function without major disruptions, networks in the following decades were routed through the suburban beach. When the Southern Cross internet cable was set up in 2000, it too landed on the Takapuna shore. In the cable industry, the prevailing logic is to go with the tried and true.

Sanford Fleming and the Canadian Government mobilized arguments about security to establish the first transpacific cable system in 1902, creating a foundational route for all north-south Pacific traffic. This system mastered the scale of the globe: the Pacific Cable Board line between Bamfield, Canada and Fanning Island was then the longest undersea cable in the world. This system also required new expenditures for infrastructure and planning. A new 8,000 ton ship, the Colonia, had to be constructed specifically for the line.

A 12th-century sea wall lines the edge of a small village where cables land. Locals come here to take in the panorama, looking east across the ocean. The clear seawater carries you up to white, rocky beaches, abutted by deep green brush leading into steep hills and low forests. The history of this village stretches back hundreds of years, when the sea wall and castle were built, forming the administrative and cultural center of the area. Yet the remoteness of the village made it appealing to cable companies during the coaxial period. After the destruction of World War II, companies surfaced cables far away from urban centers, like Okinawa City, which might be potential targets. In the 1970s and 1980s, a number of important international cables were landed here in Gushikami, making this rural land a submarine communications hub. More recently, the abandoned TPC-2 cable to Guam was revived for geophysical observations rather than telephone calls.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/bibliographicCi.value: “International Workshop on the Scientific Use of Submarine Cables,” Past Conferences – International Conferences with EM components, MTNet, accessed August 18, 2013, http://mtnet.dias.ie/conferences/1997/cables97.txt.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: The Okinawa - Luzon - Hong Kong cable, like others of this period, was given an acronym that combined the first letters of the places that were connected: OLUHO. It was not until the fiber-optic period and the break-up of the consortium system that this naming practice began to shift to use more symbolic and less descriptive terms.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: Transpacific Cable-2 established a shortcut across the ocean. While all previous cables across the Northern Pacific had stopped at Midway Island, and sometimes Wake Island, TPC-2 jumped straight from Hawai‘i to Guam, leapfrogging the nodes in between.

On the south-western coast of Australia, Cottesloe is a popular beach town and a comfortable suburb of Perth, the largest city in Western Australia. Green manicured lawns lead to soft white beaches, where families picnic and groups of people play beach cricket. When the beach is quieter, you might run across a troop of wild kangaroos rummaging through the garbage or sunning themselves on the sand. A few miles inland, the city of Perth rises above the beaches. Skyscrapers reflect the southern sun and sailboats dot the harbor. Over a century ago, in 1901, Cottesloe was chosen as the endpoint for the trans-Indian Ocean telegraph cable. The Eastern Extension Cable Company built its cable station, a bunker-like red brick building, at the edge of the ocean, on a rocky, limestone coast abutting the sea. At the southernmost end of “The Esplanade,” a wide grassy park that still exists today, the men in this building received signals from the cable and transmitted them via landline to Perth, already an established city by the time the cable station was built, with shops, streetcars, and a railway station. The cablemen had busy jobs in an exciting port, transmitting news to and from the city at all hours, every day. In this way, even though they were remotely located, they remained connected and integral to the fast-paced, urban life. In 1937, the Manager of the Cable Station boasted that “the only time throughout the entire year when there is a cessation of activity in these stations, is on Armistice Day, when the instruments are closed down for a period of two minutes.”

http://purl.org/dc/terms/bibliographicCi.value: Margaret Miller, Gentlemen of the Cable Service: A Pictorial History of Australia’s Overseas Cable Telecommunications Service, 1870-1934 (Sydney: OTC Australia and Publimedia, 1992), 10.
“A Fifteen Minute Broadcast Given by Mr. H. A. Colliver of Cottesloe Branch,” The Zodiac (1937): 276.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: Doubtless Bay, at the tip of New Zealand's North Island, was the landing site of the Pacific Cable Board's link from 1902 to 1912. The cable layers initially considered the Parengarenga Harbour, closer to the island's North Cape, but the location was too far from populated areas. Ahipara, on the west coast, was also considered, but this too was far from any existing telegraph lines. Although Doubtless Bay - far enough north, yet still possessing infrastructure - was established as a final middle ground, it was eventually replaced by Auckland as the entry point for New Zealand's northward-bound signal traffic. The remnants of the cable, rendered inoperational over a over a century ago, continues to surface periodically on the beach and pieces have been cut out of it for the regional museum.

Sanford Fleming and the Canadian Government mobilized arguments about security to establish the first transpacific cable system in 1902, creating a foundational route for all north-south Pacific traffic. This system mastered the scale of the globe: the Pacific Cable Board line between Bamfield, Canada and Fanning Island was then the longest undersea cable in the world. This system also required new expenditures for infrastructure and planning. A new 8,000 ton ship, the Colonia, had to be constructed specifically for the line.

As the highest tonnage port in Australia, Port Hedland is a place of transit and transition. Vessels crowd the water – shipping boats, cruise ships, tugboats. They navigate slowly around oil wharves that hover farther out at sea. The same companies who drill for oil also extract natural gas from beneath the ocean’s surface. A few hundred kilometers inland, miners harvest iron ore and sending it to Port Hedland via one of the many railway lines terminating there. This is a place where resources, both natural and human, are transferred between networks. From 1991 to 2004, the immigration detention facility here held a large numbers of asylum-seekers that entered Australia by boat. The JASURAUS fiber-optic cable, laid in 1997, was just one more network that connected Australia to the world, circuiting a high-speed flow of information in and out of the busy port. Yet the process of interconnecting this system was far from easy. To protect it from the port's traffic, the cable company had to design an elaborate trenching scheme that would bury the cable fifty kilometers out to sea along a long shallow shelf. After this drawn out and exasperating process, the companies returned to the previous landing, in Perth, for their next cable. More recently, in 2014, plans were floated for another submarine system, this time linking Port Hedland to liquified natural gas platforms in Australia's Browse Basin.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/bibliographicCi.value: “Mining revs up again in the Pilbara,” The Sydney Morning Herald, accessed June 19, 2013, http://www.smh.com.au/news/business/mining-revs-up-again-in-the-pilbara/2006/01/10/1136863238766.html.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: Just south of San Francisco's famous cliff house, on Ocean Beach, thousands of people reportedly watched the transpacific cable land here in 1902. San Francisco had been the hub of telegraph on the United States' west coast since the mid nineteenth century. The first Overland Telegraph, establishing communication between San Francisco and New York City, had been completed in 1861. It was not until 1873 that San Diego, Los Angeles, and Santa Barbara were connected via telegraph. From the late nineteenth century through the beginning of the twentieth century, San Francisco remained the exit point for west-bound US telegraph traffic, all of which funneled out via the city.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/title.value: Pacific Telegraph and Telephone Company building

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: For roughly two decades beginning in the late 1970s, this small village in the northwest Philippines was linked to the urban centers of Singapore, Hong Kong, and Okinawa. By 1980, Currimao was considered one of the largest and most advanced cable hubs in the world. But when the Asia-America Gateway system was being built in the early 2000s, the Philippine Long Distance Telephone Company selected a landing site more than a hundred miles south in the province of La Union, closer to Metro Manila. As quickly as it appeared, Currimao faded from the network map. Today it is perhaps best known for a series of coral rock formations, shaped by the ocean into dramatic caverns and spires over thousands of years.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: Walking around this cable landing, you take care not to fall in the ditches carved into the landscape. Trash clutters the cable landing area, and nearby, shots are fired at the end of Rifle Range Road. The station at Vatuwaqa, like so many others, was built in a largely industrial, suburban area just north of a major city, Suva. Yet unlike many cable stations, it is a place where people as well as signals come together. Men who work for Fiji's international telecommunications company are hanging out around the station. A dog lazily watches the front gate. Inside is a room constructed specifically for teleconferencing. Visiting, you find a sense of camaraderie and hospitality among the cable workers -- this is a place for meeting. In the courtyard, a monument commemorates the site's development as a satellite earth station, the landing point of the ANZCAN cable, and later, the Southern Cross system.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/rightsHolder.value: Interchange
Tonga Communications Corporation,  Government of Tonga

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: Landing on Midway, you glide up a soft white sandy beach to green grasses. Before 1903, the island was completely desolate, with little vegetation. When the Commercial Pacific Cable Company established the Midway cable station, the high winds and blinding glare of the white sand meant that cablemen had to wear goggles when they went outside. Shiploads of soil were brought in from Hawai‘i so that they could plant grass. The cable company imported chickens, cows, trees, and other plant life to make the area shady and sustainable. The cablemen recount that they found the Island “bare and have made it beautiful.” Life on Midway was quiet and lonely for the twenty-four men stationed there, over 1300 miles away from the nearest inhabited island, but they took pride in their tropical home. They issued “A Weekly Newspaper Published Every Now and Then.” One article records an “exciting day” on which a ship passed nearby the island, but “it is hardly necessary to add, did not stop." After the Second World War, and the infamous battle that occurred here, Midway continued to be a key node in cable networks, first as a stopping point for the first transpacific telephone cable and later as a cable listening post for the U.S. Navy's Sound Surveillance System.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/bibliographicCi.value: “The Transformation of Midway Island,” The Zodiac: The Journal of the Submarine Cable Service XI, no. 129 (April 1919): 230.
“The Gooney Clarion,” The Zodiac 6, no. 61-72 (June 1912- May 1913).

“Midway Island,” History of the Atlantic Cable & Undersea Communications: from the first submarine cable of 1850 to the worldwide fiber optic network, accessed June 7, 2013, http://atlantic-cable.com/CableCos/Midway/.
Wikipedia contributors, “Midway Atoll,” Wikipedia, The Free Encyclopedia, accessed June 7, 2013, http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Midway_Atoll.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: You are carried to shore at Baler with nine-foot waves surging overhead, curling in on themselves and frothing as they meet the warm, sandy beach. A smattering of palm trees line the coast, and before you, the earth rises up in rolling green mountains filled with waterfalls, caves, and springs. A cable landing point since 1964, Baler has become famous more for its surf than its land. Especially from October to March, when the waves are greatest, the sea fills with surfers who flock to Baler’s beaches. The waves loom large in people’s minds here: locals claim that sometimes the surf is so huge that they can hear it from the provincial capitol building, 1.5 km away from the coast. Like the cable, surfing came to this town because of global media flows. The film Apocalypse Now was shot here in the 1970s, and included a famous scene of American soldiers surfing. After filming, the crew left behind their boards and a new sport.

“The outside world, with its quips and cranks, is shut out, and we are a community unto ourselves,” one cableman writes of New Zealand’s first undersea telegraph station, established in 1876. Relatively isolated from the nearest town, and with few women present, the cablemen of the Wakapuaka station formed a tight-knit family, one built on male comradeship in work and play. They spent their off-hours fishing in the bay, playing tennis at the station’s courts, producing a Saturday night theatrical show, and drinking heavily. They recalled memorable events in their amateur “newspaper,” the Cable Bay Recorder, which took a sometimes satirical spin on station life. By the early 1890s, Cable Bay became a recruitment point and training station for the telegraph company, at times drawing new men in through family contacts. Station life flourished, increasing staff from only 7 to 17, but competition from the Pacific Cable Board in the north and a fire that damaged the station’s architecture, reduced the vibrant station life and ultimately guided the company’s decision to move the landing to Wellington in 1917. Today, recreational travelers to Cable Bay Holiday Park learn about the area's history from the images of station life, memorialized on its walls.

In 1876 the Eastern Telegraph Company laid a trans-Tasman cable from Botany Bay to Nelson, where they sought to interconnect with economic trade then centralized in New Zealand’s South Island. A recollection of this link, the first to New Zealand, proclaims: “Cut off by 13,000 miles of sea, and six months in time, from their homeland, British colonists living in remote New Zealand in 1876 suddenly found themselves linked with England—of nostalgic memory—by submarine cable. Thirty-six years of isolation was at an end.”

A second cable was laid by Eastern Extension between La Perouse, Australia and Nelson, New Zealand in 1890, where it would function until 1917, when it was relocated to nearby urban centers in Sydney and Wellington.

Located in the Indian Ocean, close to Africa, this 108 square kilometer piece of earth was formed by volcanic eruptions 1.5 million years ago, making it very small, and geologically, very young. The island was uninhabited by humans for most of its short history, yet bustled with unique plant and animal life, unaffected by intervention or cultivation. Throughout the 17th and 18th century both the Dutch and the French tried to settle and farm the island, their efforts stymied by loneliness more than by the land itself. The French, who had brought African slaves from Mauritius, eventually gave up on farming and exhausted the island’s large tortoise population by using it to supply meat to passing ships. When the British took possession of the island in 1809, slavery was abolished and the freed slaves and colonists built a small but somewhat stable economy through tobacco and food exports. With commerce comes communication, and in 1901 the British landed a telegraph cable here, stopping between Mauritius and the Cocos Islands, and making this tiny place an essential node.

Patrice Donzelot, “Internet: Europe Wants to Finance the Cable to Rodrigues,” Mauritius | Hi-Tech, http://business.mega.mu, accessed June 25, 2013, http://business.mega.mu/2013/05/07/internet-europe-wants-finance-cable-rodrigues/.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: You land in Spencer Beach Park, a gentle, sandy beach in a protected inlet on the northwestern tip of the island of Hawai‘i. The ocean is calm and clear. Snorkelers glide across the surface, peering at the colorful fish who dart through the waters below. Closer to shore, children splash around and wade up to the sand, where their families are picnicking. A bit farther inland, some campers sit at the opening of their tent and watch the ocean. Hawai‘i, “the big island” in the archipelago that makes up the state of Hawai‘i, is more sparsely populated than O’ahu, where the older the Hawaiian cables have landed. While recent cables encountered opposition from locals when they landed in O’ahu, at Spencer Beach there were celebrations upon arrival of a system from Tahiti, featuring traditional Hawaiian dance and song.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/bibliographicCi.value: Bill Glover, “Cable Timeline: 1951-2000,” History of the Atlantic Cable & Undersea Communications: from the first submarine cable of 1850 to the worldwide fiber optic network, accessed July 19, 2013, http://atlantic-cable.com/Cables/CableTimeLine/index1951.htm.

“Samuel M Spencer Beach Cable Landing Site,” Submarine Cable Networks: the World of Submarine Cable Systems and Networks, http://submarinenetworks.com, accessed July 19, 2013, http://submarinenetworks.com/stations/north-america/usa-hawaii/samuel-m-spencer-beach.

Bill Glover, “Cable Timeline: 2001-,” History of the Atlantic Cable & Undersea Communications: from the first submarine cable of 1850 to the worldwide fiber optic network, accessed July 19, 2013, http://atlantic-cable.com/Cables/CableTimeLine/index2001.htm.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: In 2010, the Honotua cable – stretching between Hawai‘i and Tahiti – was made possible by funding from the French Government, granted as part of a wider measure to extend broadband to French citizens and improve the country’s digital economy.

In Australia, cables were brought ashore at Botany Bay, the site where Captain Cook first staked the British Flag in 1770 and where French explorer La Perouse landed in 1788. Although it was ten kilometers south of Sydney, Botany Bay was selected as a cable site in part due to this proximity to nautical traffic and ship landings, which in turn helped to attract military and defense installations. Even after the telegraph station closed for signal traffic, the building continued to serve surrounding publics – emergent circulations continued to leverage the resources of existing nodes. It was used briefly as quarters for Coast Hospital nurses and subsequently as a women’s refuge operated by the Salvation Army. Traffic was eventually redirected to central Sydney, landing at Bondi Beach, where internet traffic continues to enter Australia. The builders of at least one subsequent cable system, however, still toyed with the idea of returning to La Perouse. The old cable station building, now a museum housing the artifacts of transnational communication; a nearby watchtower, originally meant to look out for smugglers; and a monument named for the early French explorer all serve as reminders of the location’s significance in drawing in heterogeneous historical currents.

Wandering on New Zealand’s west coast, you find a coaxial cable extending out from a sand bank, over a small pond of water, and back into the beach before it heads to Sydney. Aquatic creatures have incorporated its eroding armor and still strong copper core into their home. Old cables dating to the telegraph era have surfaced on this beach: the first international link landed over a century ago, in 1912. Cost-cutting during the Depression prompted the cable company to re-locate a second link, formerly in Wellington, here in 1932. From Muriwai cables extend inland over twenty miles to the growing city of Auckland. This terrestrial path is almost as fraught as the surf-beaten shores of Muriwai. In 1952, incorrectly gauging the location of the cable system, a road grader severed the international network for five hours. After this, the cable companies ensured that the network was extensively marked for the local community.

A mere twelve feet above sea level, this string of three islands is the only evidence of a massive volcano that lies beneath. Wake, Pearle, and Wilkes Island wrap around a shallow, vibrant blue lagoon, the volcano's empty crater. Dangers are hidden on the atoll's shores, in the military installations from which the United States coordinates another kind of aerial explosion: military missile testing. Were it not for undersea cables, this island might never have become a United States possession. It was discovered in 1568 by Spanish explorers, but was dubbed a “low barren island.” In 1899, the US government annexed Wake Island with the hope of landing a cable there, but given the lack of fresh water and its unhospitable conditions, a station was never built. It was not until after the historic battle on Wake Island during World War II that it finally became a cable node. In 1964, the United States and Japan coordinated to land the first transpacific telephone cable here. Although all systems skipped over the island, Wake continues to serve a strategic function. Hydroacoustic arrays extend out to the seafloor, monitoring for underwater nuclear activity in the Western Pacific.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: Long before it was a cable hub, Katong was a center of private wealth in British Malaya. Colonial elites established giant mansions, coconut plantations, and weekend villas along the waterfront in this East Singapore district beginning in the early nineteenth century. Though some of these structures have been preserved and restored, often painted bright colors, the still-affluent neighborhood has also seen some major physical transformations. The beach where you emerge from the APCN-2 network didn’t even exist before the 1970s. It was created as part of a massive land-reclamation project designed to add more space for housing on the island. Modern apartment towers and Singapore’s largest park now occupy the expanded coastal area. Soon after the artificial beach was completed, a telephone cable arrived from Hong Kong, followed by connections to regional fiber-optic networks in the 1990s and early 2000s.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/rightsHolder.value: SingTel,  Verizon Business,  KDDI,  Chunghwa Telecom,  AT&T,  BT,  France Telecom,  Softbank Telecom,  NTT,  Tata Communications,  Telekom Malaysia,  Starhub,  PLDT,  China Unicom,  KT,  SingTel Optus,  Telstra,  PCCW,  China Telecom,  LG Uplus,  New World Telecom,  Vodafone

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: The ASEAN (Association of South East Asian Nations) submarine cable was inaugurated in 1983 by “a three-way conversation among the Communications Ministers of Malaysia, Singapore, and Thailand,” reports the New Straits Times. With landing stations in all three countries, the cable had a capacity of 1,680 telephone lines and carried telegraph and telex messages as well. But the inauguration placed the most emphasis on the cable system’s political significance. It represented “the unity, understanding, and cooperation among the five ASEAN nations” and “exemplified their strong dedication to work towards common objectives beneficial to all.”

http://purl.org/dc/terms/bibliographicCi.value: Source: “Three-way Link-up launched,” New Straits Times, 28 September 1983: 2.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: The British colony of Adelaide entered the underwater network in 1872. Telegraph signals traveled through overland lines to Port Darwin and, from there, to London via Singapore and India. Previously, messages between Europe and Australia were carried by ship and took upwards of eighty days to reach their destinations. Now they could be sent in a matter of hours. In 1901, Adelaide received its first submarine connection to the old world by way of Perth and Durban, South Africa. “Whilst buoying” the cable offshore near Kangaroo Island, notes an Eastern Extension Company cable ship officer, it “got foul of the propellers on account of the strong current; it took us six hours to get it clear, but no damage was done.” Once untangled, the line joined Adelaide’s General Post and Telegraph Office, a grand, stone and brick building adorned with a clock tower. Built in the early 1870s to receive the first international telegraph signals, the station was soon expanded to include a telephone exchange.

Palembang is not on a coast, but about 40 miles inland from the South China Sea, in the south-east corner of Sumatra. But the city has been an important trading and maritime center for millennia due to its location on the Musi River. This wide, grey river runs through the town, dividing the city into halves, and, during the colonial period, easily receiving large military and merchant ships. On one bank, a walled city was built by the Dutch, while the opposite bank remained lined with smaller traditional wooden houses on stilts with deep red roofs. The Musi River both divided and connected – it made it easier for the Dutch East Indies Company to open a trading post here in 1619, and by the 18th century, over 50,000 pounds of spices were exported from the city every year. The telegraph cable, brought in 1859, was used in part to transmit information about this trade. The last section of cable had to be laid using proas, local vessels which snaked 60 miles of cable up the narrow and deep river to its widening at the shores of Palembang.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: In 1903, the Eastern Extension Australasia and China Telegraph Company was invited by the Dutch East Indies government “to connect Java, Borneo, and Sumatra with the islands of Billiton and Banka [Belitung and Bangka],” notes an issue of The Electrician from that year. “When these cables are established it is expected that they will not only prove a great convenience to the Government and mercantile community, but act as important feeders to the Company’s system” of submarine lines.

Weltevreden, Batavia is today’s Sawah Besar, a section of Jakarta, Indonesia. The area was built up and named by the Dutch East India Company in the 17th and 18th centuries. In the 19th Century it became a full-fledged Dutch colony and in 1859 a telegraph cable was laid here connecting to Hong Kong. Had you arrived at that time, you would have found an established colonial city with a busy port. The area closer to the water held warehouses and offices of many trading companies. Weltevreden was more stately, with shops and government offices. Writings from that period describe the cable station as “one of the favourite stations in the Extension Co.” – it had a rambling garden, tennis courts, stables, a reading room, and a broad entryway flanked by palm trees. Today the area still bears traces of the earlier colonial period. The central square, laid out by the Dutch in the 19th century, displays symmetrical paths and gardens lined with palm trees, which lead to a statue celebrating Indonesia’s independence. In the same neighborhood, a large cathedral sits nearby a temple that is home to both Buddhist and Hindu practitioners, built in Dutch Colonial style.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/bibliographicCi.value: Bill Glover, "Cable Timeline: 1845-1900," History of the Atlantic Cable & Undersea Communications: from the first submarine cable of 1850 to the worldwide fiber optic network, accessed June 29, 2013, http://atlantic-cable.com/Cables/CableTimeLine/index1850.htm.
“Batavia: The Exiles' Mess,” The Zodiac, 1922. Held in the Cable & Wireless Archives.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: On December 31, 1870, Madras, India (the colonial name for the city now known as Chennai) received its first underwater telegraph line, which linked India to Malaysia. The telegraph station in Madras was connected in the other direction to overland lines, controlled by the Indian government, reaching across the subcontinent to Bombay. One of the last British ports to be developed, Madras lacked a proper harbor until 1890. Due to the city’s shallow coastal plain, ships had to offload cargo from nearly a quarter mile out to sea, and only then when waters were calm. When the Telcon cable ship arrived, recounts an Australian crewmember, rafts and surfboats were used to bring the line close to the beach before it was “hauled on shore by natives through the surf which is heavy there.” A successful test of the Madras-Penang connection was celebrated with a dinner on the ship and, later that evening, a New Year’s Eve party at the Madras town hall “to which we were all invited, it was a grand affair.”

http://purl.org/dc/terms/bibliographicCi.value:
Selected sources:
Jorma Ahvenainen, The Far Eastern Telegraphs: The History of Telegraphic Communication between the Far East, Europe and America before the First World War. Helsinki: Suomalainen Tiedeakatemia, 1981. 19.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: This system, the first link from India to Asia, was extended by the British Indian Extension Telegraph Company in 1870.

Here you are received by Japanese hands. Annexed in 1910, Annam-ri remained under Japanese control until the end of World War II. The village is about 100 miles east from Japan’s westernmost island, and during the annexation, the Japanese government brought three cables ashore. The spot is ideal for a safe landing: a protected and quiet inlet with flat, grey waters and sandy beaches. Evergreen trees cover the gentle mountains sloping up past the beach. You don’t wonder where you are going next – there is but one option. Signals only shuttle back and forth from here to Japan.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/bibliographicCi.value: Bill Glover, “Cable Timeline: 1901-1950,” History of the Atlantic Cable & Undersea Communications: from the first submarine cable of 1850 to the worldwide fiber optic network, accessed June 22, 2013, http://atlantic-cable.com/Cables/CableTimeLine/index1901.htm.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: Vladivostok is located at the south-easternmost tip of Russia, on the hills that rise at the head of the Zoltoy Rog Bay. The harbor’s name means “Golden Horn,” and references a similarly shaped harbor in Constantinople. Both cities grew up on the edge of their states and became important ending and beginning points for travel, shipping, and communication. In the early 1870s, when the Great Northern Telegraph Company established a cable landing at this site, the city was a busy trading port with a shipbuilding yard, which welcomed new settlers. Vladivostok’s first street was built in 1871, winding from the bay uphill to the wooden and stone residences that were rapidly appearing throughout the city. That same year the cable arrived, connecting Russia to Nagasaki and on to Shanghai. The telegraph office sat in a stately three-story office building at the corner of two major streets. By the turn of the twentieth-century, Vladivostok had developed into a modern city with tall buildings, shops, and hotels. The Trans-Siberian Railway, built at the same time, terminated in Vladivostok, connecting this easternmost edge of Russia to Moscow. Today, Vladivostok is the largest Russian port on the Pacific Ocean and is a busy city of about 500,000 people. People and goods still ebb and flow through this bay. The Russky Bridge, completed in 2012, is the largest cable-stayed bridge in the world, hovering over the Eastern Bosphorus Strait and connecting Vladivostok to Russky Island.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: This cable system was extended by the Great Northern Telegraph Company in 1871, during a boom period of telegraph building, to connect Russia, Japan, China, and Hong Kong.

The first and last submarine link to connect Infanta was landed in 1990. Known as the “gateway to the Pacific,” this medium-sized port city is located on a tiny peninsula that juts into the Polillo Strait, leading to the Philippine Sea. In the 1990s, the city led a double life as a manufacturing center for the province and a quiet escape destination. Straw-roofed resort huts dot the blue-green waters. The city itself sprawls inward with two-story buildings housing banks, offices, shops, and restaurants. Farther inland, logging sites and salt flats ship their spoils to the town. More recently, the city literally had to dig out from natural disaster: a monsoon in 2004 set off a mudslide in the nearby mountains, burying Infanta in millions of cubic meters of mud, water, cut logs, and uprooted trees. The cable escaped the catastrophe, having gone out of service just a year before.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/bibliographicCi.value: Bill Glover, “Cable Timeline: 1951-2000,” History of the Atlantic Cable & Undersea Communications: from the first submarine cable of 1850 to the worldwide fiber optic network, accessed July 16, 2013, http://atlantic-cable.com/Cables/CableTimeLine/index1951.htm.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: Pantai Mutiara is the name for an elegant and chic neighborhood on Jakarta Bay. Neoclassical mansions, contemporary skyscrapers filled with luxury apartments, yacht clubs, restaurants, and pricey bars line the water here. There are golf clubs on either side of the pier, and delicately manicured terraces in front of most buildings. In such rarefied surroundings, it’s hard to imagine the act of landing a cable from the dredges of the ocean’s bottom. Yet this where the Matrix Cable System connects to Jakarta from Singapore. To land here, they bought and converted a beach area condo to house their cable station.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/bibliographicCi.value: Muli Muljati, "Indonesia Domestic Backbone," Indonesia Submarine Cables, slideshare.net, accessed July 19, 2013, http://www.slideshare.net/mulimuljati/indonesia-domestic-fibre-optic.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: Electric Beach, on O‘ahu’s west shore, is named for the large power plant towering behind it and known for regular car burglaries. Three men casually fish off the edge of the point. Families barbeque. A manhole is covered in rusty red dirt. Moving under this manhole, through the cable, and out to the ocean, you briefly pass a small cave with hanging clothes, stockpiled chairs, and collected water. The same beach that makes possible the landing of communications cables – infrastructures that accelerate the movement of information across the oceans – is also a temporary dwelling for some of the least mobile Hawaiians. The Kahe Point station, constructed just north of Electric Beach, has managed to stay out of view, and therefore out of local politics.

The first cables to land in Manila led a fraught life, as did the city itself. Already a fortified and busy trading center, Spain took possession of Manila in the 16th century and it became an important node for the traffic of goods to the New World. By the late 19th century, the cobblestone streets were busy with shops, businesses, and horse-and-buggies. With this growth there was also great resistance, which disrupted the smoothness of signal traffic. In 1880 a cable was laid to Hong Kong, extending from Manila over land to Bolinao, an arduous process. By the time the cable station finally opened for service in 1887, the Philippine Revolution was in full swing. The link was repeatedly cut by revolutionary forces, and within a year, it was replaced by a submarine cable landing in Manila Bay. Yet even that cable was not safe from strife – the Spanish-American War started in 1898, and it, too, was cut during battle. After the Americans won that war, the ensuing brutal and bloody Philippine – American War left up to 1 million Filipino casualties. Eager to establish themselves after their victory, the Americans laid another cable, connecting Manila to the United States.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: There are only a few ways to get ashore at Norfolk Island. Rough sees batter the island’s high, rocky walls. There are no harbors or ports. Strong currents make entry difficult at the one feasible cable landing site, Anson Bay, and even here landslides can take out the hillside. Despite these difficulties, the island was determined to be the only feasible geographic location to land the first transpacific cable after it snaked down from Fiji and before it branched off to Australia and New Zealand. Norfolk’s inaccessibility had once made it an ideal location for a convict settlement, yet this had been closed almost fifty years prior to the cable’s arrival. Migrants from Pitcairn, the descendants of the Bounty mutineers, have taken up residence in the penal buildings. The island’s insularity coupled with a lack of traffic produced a set of unique connections. For a period of time, the cableman on night duty in Southport would send newspaper extracts to Norfolk Island, where they were typed up by the operator and “tacked up on a tree at the crossroads for all to read.” This news source was known as the “Tree of Knowledge.” By the 1920s, with the development of automatic relays, far fewer staff were needed on Norfolk.

Fanning Island was linked via the Pacific Cable Board's telegraph cable in 1902. It was the most geographically remote station on the line, and cable men often dreaded moving there. Ernest Shackelton, famed Antarctic explorer, once wrote a poem about Fanning Island, a “lonely islet” on which Pacific Cable Board’s communications depended:

“Surf-bound, lonely islet,
Set in a summer sea,
Work of a tiny insect
A lesson I learn from Thee—
For to your foam-white shores
The deep sea cables come;
Through slippery ooze, by feathery palm
Flies by the busy hum
Of Nations linked together,
The young with the older lands,
A moment’s space, and the Northern tale
Is placed in Southern hands—”

On Fanning Island, the relationship of dependency (islands typically depend on mainlands) is inverted: the island was integral part of a chain leading to and supporting the British Empire.

Tourists step on a long cable conduit without looking twice, intent on getting to the ruins of an Japanese antiaircraft gun constructed during World War II at the far end of Gun Beach. Guam held strategic military value in part due to its position as a cable hub. At the other end of the beach is the Hotel Nikko, one of the early Japanese five star hotels in the area, a structure dependent on the island’s advanced communications  infrastructure. Undersea cables, shuttling signals to the United States, Australia, and Japan, bisect a material remnant of the Japanese wartime attack and one of the largest indications of Japanese development on the island, two sites with which undersea cables are intertwined. The cable conduits themselves are worn down and blend in with the rocks on the beach. In the water their surfaces are smooth, but rippled, like the ocean. In them, you can see traces of the atmospheric and geological currents that have long positioned the island as central to transpacific movement. Tumon Bay is a node in the cable network, a point of interconnection and redistribution, not simply of electronic signals, but of cultural and political currents.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/rightsHolder.value: AT&T
Softbank Telecom,  NTT,  Telstra,  Verizon Business,  AT&T

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: Long before Bandon became AT&T’s outpost in rural Oregon, it was a critical node in an undersea cable network: the U.S. military’s Sound Surveillance System (SOSUS). From the Pacific coast, SOSUS connected hydrophones and picked up sonic traces of subaquatic movements, from the deployment of Soviet submarines to migrations of whales. Officers stationed at Naval Facility Coos Head tuned into these underwater listening posts and collected data on enemy operations. The Coos Head facility, first opened in 1958, was closed twenty-nine years later in 1987. Improvements in signal-processing had replaced manpower with computers, and as the Cold War wound down the number of Naval Facilities was reduced. Given AT&T’s tight ties with the U.S. Navy, and their assistance in developing SOSUS, it was unsurprising when nine years later, they chose Bandon as a landing point for their newest transpacific cable system, TPC-5.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/rightsHolder.value: Verizon Business,  AT&T,  KDDI,  Tata Communications,  China Telecom,  Chunghwa Telecom,  KT,  NTT,  Level 3,  SingTel,  Sprint,  Telekom Malaysia,  Telecom New Zealand,  Telstra,  PCCW,  LG Uplus,  Softbank Telecom,  Rostelecom,  SingTel Optus,  France Telecom

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: The Tanguisson Beach station, built to house American networks during the Cold War era, resembles an underground bunker. Entering, you descend several stories down a fortified stairwell and even then, can only access the equipment room once admitted through a secure metal door. Immediately inside the entrance is a decontamination chamber, a former precaution for nuclear attack, and now a storage closet. Everything inside is redundant in case the domestic infrastructure fails. Multiple, completely separated generators comprise backups for building power and air-conditioning units. Independent battery plants sustain the equipment. During the coaxial era, Tanguisson was staffed by at least two employees at all times, but was often occupied by many more. On the wall, you witness evidence of the community formed here: yearbook-style photos of all of the AT&T stations in the Pacific: Makaha, Keawa‘ula, Bandon, San Luis Obispo, and Manchester. Each has an image of the station, and photos of the people who worked there, with their name and position listed underneath, grouped as a school class would be. Photographs of the cable ships, AT&T cable landings, and maps of Guam decorate the walls. Due to the massive downsizings that have occurred since the 1980s, far fewer people work at Tanguisson today. The cable community, however, still exists.

Entering service in March 1999, this optical cable connects the Philippine Long Distance Telephone Company’s station in Batangas with AT&T’s landing point in Guam, where connections are made to several Asia-U.S. networks. It was designed to complement and ease congestion along existing Asian and trans-Pacific cable systems.
