http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: In 1893, New Caledonia is changing. The prisoners have almost all left, and commerce is coming. A telegraph cable is being landed on New Caledonia’s soft shores. Inland, low brush and flowering bushes lead to dry meadows dotted with trees, providing little obstacle to the cable. Farther in, green and brown peaks soar upwards. Almost three decades earlier, nickel was discovered in these mountains, and since then the French have been mining the island. Despite their efforts at immigration, New Caledonia is now largely unpopulated by Europeans. Not long ago, the island was a French penal colony, where over 20,000 criminals and political prisoners were held. Many of them were Communards, punished for creating a self-governing socialist society in Paris. The cells emptied out when they were granted amnesty in 1879. With the discovery of nickel, the place began to serve a new purpose, and the French government hoped to establish itself in the South Pacific by making New Caledonia a hub.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/bibliographicCi.value: ll Glover, “Australian Cables,” History of the Atlantic Cable & Undersea Communications: from the first submarine cable of 1850 to the worldwide fiber optic network, accessed June 22, 2013, http://www.atlantic-cable.com/CableCos/Australia/.
"Queensland-New Caledonia Cable, 1893-1923," National Archives of Australia, Brisbane Office, J2774 J2774/1, W11308.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.value: 1893-1898, as per Atlantic-Cable.com, or 1925, as per archival records in iPhoto

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: The French company, La Societe Française des Télégraphes Sous-Marins, extended this cable from the Australian coast to New Caledonia in 1893, as part of a project to link France to its colonies.

Until recently French Polynesia relied on wireless means of communication, but due to the scarcity of satellites in the South Pacific, the cost for bandwidth remained high for its approximately 270,000 residents. In 2010 the Honotua cable—stretching from Tahiti to Hawai‘i—was made possible by funding from the French government, granted as part of a measure to extend broadband to all French citizens and bridge the digital divide. Honotua was not seen simply as a technical bridge to a global network, but as part of, and emanating from, local language and mythology. Ceremonies were staged at the cable landings, where men and women danced in traditional native attire. The cable was named in Tahitian: hono means a link and tua means the back, backbone, or far ocean. Legend has it that the link traces the route of the Tahitian Queen, who long ago lived at the cable landing site at Papenoo, and had traveled to the landing site at Hawai‘i. The cable company laying the system learned of a second coincidence after the cable had already been named. The local mayor informed them that a man who lived near the landing had a relative named Honotua, yet another connection of cable to local genealogy.

Port Alberni draws its wealth from the vast forest of British Columbia’s shores. Deep inland, sheltered from the Pacific Ocean by a long, narrow inlet, the town’s early dwellers worked at waterfront mills, stripping the woods around them to make products that circled the globe. By the 1960s, many residents worked for MacMillan Bloedel, one of the world’s largest forestry companies. It not only boosted the region’s economy, but each of its divisions had its own social club, organizing social gatherings of all kinds and structuring local life. Yet in the 1960s and 70s, a new constituency began to oppose the logging of Vancouver Island. Environmentalists called for the protection of nature and the establishment of parks. When first undersea telephone link, COMPAC, arrived in 1963, there was a clash between the Canadian Overseas Telecommunications Service and environmentalists when the company cleared forest for cables connecting to the COMPAC system. The cable was ultimately landed with no problems, the cable coming ashore amidst logs, swerving uphill next to the Alberni Plywood Division.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.value: Was located at 44 Northam Road, now Jalan Sultan Ahmad Shah.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: In George Town at the turn of the 19th century you witness the beginnings of a modern city. The streets are lined with warehouses and ghauts, wide steps leading from the street to the water. Banks, trading areas, and emporium stores are beginning to appear along Beach Street. Since its founding by the British East India Company in 1786, the town has grown into a bustling trading port and commercial center. George Town has been built on water: its commercial center stands on a swampy wetland that was leveled and filled in the early 1800s. Seeing that this was precarious, English settlers built their bungalows high up on top of Penang Hill, forbidding natives to do the same. The settlers’ wealthy Chinese business partners were allowed to build in the middle part of the hill. The cable – part of the emerging modern city – surfaces close to the water, but ultimately connected those who lived far above it.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/bibliographicCi.value: Bill Glover, “Cable Timeline: 1845-1900,” History of the Atlantic Cable & Undersea Communications: from the first submarine cable of 1850 to the worldwide fiber optic network, accessed June 22, 2013, http://atlantic-cable.com/Cables/CableTimeLine/index1850.htm.
Visions of Penang Archives Online (My Heritage My Penang), accessed June 22, 2013, http://www.visionsofpenang.com.my

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: A link between Penang and Rangoon was manufactured by Telcon and laid by the Eastern Extension Australasia & China Telegraph Company in 1877.

“On December 15,” declares a U.S. trade report, “the Eastern Telegraph Co.’s new cable from Penang to Colombo was established and its new cable system thrown open to traffic with London and with the Far East.” This 1913 cable was part of a much longer 12,000-mile connection between Lands End, England and Hong Kong (via Suez, Aden, Colombo, Penang, and Singapore). By avoiding slower overland lines and stopping points where a message has to be deciphered and retransmitted, the submarine cable greatly increased the speed and reliability of communication between Britain and its settlements in Asia.
In 1891, the British Eastern Extension, Australasia & China Telegraph Company extended their networks to Medan.

A century ago, Yap was a Pacific communications hub, the junction point of three cables linking Guam, Shanghai, and Manado. Colonized by Germany, it was a critical node in their vast cable network of over 18,000 miles. From Guam, the United States relied on the German-Netherlands network to connect to Shanghai. Yap formed an important bridge between America and China. During World War I, the Japanese seized the island and Yap became not only a “cable threat,” but a threat to the sea route between the U.S. and the Philippines. After the war, the possession of Yap, its cables, and its coaling station was the subject of a dispute between the United States and Japan. Japan claimed that the island had been designated to her under a Mandate of the League of Nations. The United States sought to put Yap under “International supervision” as an international cable station, rather than under control of a single nation. After a year of deadlock, the United States and Japan came to an agreement that split the network, and subsequently eliminated all cable links. Today, Yap remains without cable systems and without high-speed Internet infrastructure, linked only via wireless technologies. A single satellite station carries all of Yap’s traffic out of the country.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/title.value: Yap Federal States of Micronesia Telecommunications Corporation

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: This cable, originally laid by the German-Netherlands Telegraph company, was diverted to Okinawa by the Japanese in 1916.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.value: 1942, diversion of the 1905 Guam - Yap - Menado cable

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: In 1942, Japan diverted a German cable (originally laid in 1905 between Menado, Yap, and Guam) to Palau, where it had military installations and regional government headquarters from 1914 to 1944.
This cable, originally laid by the German-Netherlands Telegraph Company, was diverted by the Japanese to Palau in 1942.
In 1916, this cable was moved from Shanghai to Okinawa by the Japanese Military.

Like so many Indonesian cities, Makassar developed under the influence of European spice trades starting in the 16th century. The Dutch came in the 17th century and the cables began to arrive in the late 19th century, connecting this city with Bali in 1888, Balikpapan in 1905, and then with Java and Central Sulawesi in 1913. Arriving along the cable at the turn of the twentieth century, you witness the height of Dutch development: they had captured, rebuilt, and renamed the city’s central fort. The new “Fort Rotterdam” looked very much like its namesake, with manicured lawns and large stone buildings with pitched red roofs. The walled city that developed around the fort was a hub for the copra, rattan, pearls, trepang, and sandalwood trade, and enslaved local people for businessmen. Although Joseph Conrad called Makassar “the prettiest and perhaps, cleanest looking of all the towns in the islands,” such beauty reflected colonial interests.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.value: 1905, Norddeutsche Seekabelwerke, Dutch East Indies Government

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: In the 1920s, a submarine cable manufactured by the German company Norddeutsche Seekabelwerke and sponsored by the Dutch East Indies government was laid down the western coast of Sulawesi, connecting Dutch settlements on the island to Surabaya.

Kota Kinabalu is known as KK to many Malaysians and internationals, but locals also call it Api-Api, its original indigenous name, meaning fire. The rapidly growing capital of the eastern Malaysian state, Sabah, is today a culturally, ethnically, and religiously diverse city of half a million people. Many of the country’s banks and insurance companies have their headquarters in tall office buildings clustered at the edge of the sea. From 1964 to 1986, the SEACOM cable connected the city to Singapore, and onward to the global network. This was followed by a fiber-optic link, laid in 1992. KK’s status as an economic and industrial center was prefigured by the British development of its port during the colonial period. The harbor’s connection with the Asian mainland is far more ancient than either the cable or the colony, however. KK is named after nearby Mount Kinabalu, the tallest mountain in the Malay archipelago. Legend has it that Kinabalu is derived from the words for “Chinese Widow.” Long ago, the legend tells, a Chinese prince was shipwrecked in the area and fell in love with a local woman. He returned to China, but promised to come back for her. Every day at sunrise, she would make a pilgrimage to the top of the mountain to look for his ship, until one day she died on the cold summit. The spirit of the mountain turned her face into a rock facing the sea, so that she could always look out towards China.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: This cable was launched on October 19, 1992, with a press conference at the Philippine Plaza Hotel in Manila. It was part of the $320 million ASEAN Optical-Fiber Submarine Cable Network, which also included lines between Brunei and Singapore, and between two parts of Malaysia across the South China Sea.

Ninomiya was the first landing site for trans-Pacific coaxial cables in Japan, built in 1964 to receive TPC-1 from Guam. Unlike many modern stations, it is located in a central residential area populated by commuters to Odawara and Tokyo-Yokohama. Even though Ninomiya is linked to these urban areas, the greenery of Azumayama Park makes them easy to leave behind. Climb up the hill behind the station and you will enter the park, passing several shrines and temples on your journey to the summit. Dense woods open onto a grassy plain with commanding views of Sagami Bay and Mount Fuji. Artist Hokusai Katsushika included this vista in his series of woodblock prints of Fuji as seen from different Japanese towns, drawing Ninomiya into an early-nineteenth-century visual network.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/rightsHolder.value: Reliance Globalcom

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: Towards the end of the fiber-optic cable boom in the early 2000s, Tyco Telecommunications built a station in the town of Ma‘ili, seeking to tap into the torrent of information flow through O‘ahu’s west shore. It is located in the center of the town, next to an elementary school. Children play next door, their voices filtering across the lawn, over heaps of trash in an adjacent lot, and through the cable station. Yet during the cable bust, the plans collapsed and the building was put up for sale. Today, the station is abandoned and has bullet holes in its windows. No signals terminate here.

Today, Medan is the fourth largest city in Indonesia and the second busiest port. Huge shipping boats slide through the grey water, alongside long dark piers. Here, they are filled with tobacco, palm oil, tea, and rubber, before being sent back out through the Strait of Malacca. While goods flow out, people and signals flow in. The city itself is modernized and notoriously ethnically diverse, its industries requiring fast technologies and drawing a range of immigrant workers. In many ways, it is also a pilgrimage destination. Since 1906, religious devotees have traveled here to visit The Great Mosque of Medan. Today, visitors come from around Asia to feed their tastes as well as their souls: the city is known for its myriad cuisines, from Javanese cuisine, to Batak pork, Chinese noodles, and Indian curries. In 1999, a cable surfaced here connecting from Singapore, through Medan, to Penang. Medan had been an essential node in this path before – in the early 1890s, coincident with the city’s growth as a tobacco exporter, a telegraph cable was laid here connecting to Penang and Acheen. As trade continued and industry grew, so too did the information transiting the city.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: The island is an unwelcoming place, yet a center of conflict. Anton Chekov describes it quite simply as “hell.” Peopled mostly by soldiers and life-long prisoners, with a few fishermen, Alexandrovsk-Sakhalinsky is damp, cold, and icy in the winter months. A small harbor town on the island of Sakhalin, off the edge of the Russian mainland and north of the northernmost part of Japan, it became the location of a Russian military post in 1881, established to oversee the prison camps and nearby exile settlements. Political dissidents, criminals, and ethnic minorities were sent to live here in large communal cells and to work the land for the rest of their lives. Chekov lived here in 1890 while working on a treatise about the Tsarist penal system. Arriving before the completion of the Trans-Siberian railroad or the trans-Pacific cable, he traveled the 6,000 miles across Siberia by coach, and then across the water by boat to the island. He wrote of his arrival: "Along the shore near the pier some 50 convicts were wandering, obviously idle; some wore overalls, others in jackets or grey cloth coats. When I approached, they removed their caps.  It is possible that no writer has ever previously received such an honour." Fifteen years later, during the Russo-Japanese war, the southern half of the island would be taken by the Japanese and united with the island of Hokkaido by a submarine communications cable.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: In 1905, following the Russo-Japanese war, the Japanese laid a line from the northern tip of Japan to Sakhalin Island.

It’s a typical grey day in Nakhodka. Looking out across the bay, you see large shipping vessels lingering beyond the oil rigs that dot the shore. Discovered in 1859 by a Russian warship seeking shelter from a storm, Nakhodka means “lucky find” in Russian. Despite its location on the edge of Siberia, the bay is relatively calm and ice-free, making it an optimal location for dropping anchor, as well as for surfacing cable systems. Nakhodka was the site for the landing of a telephone cable to Japan in 1969, followed by several fiber-optic links carrying internet traffic. As is true for many of the postwar systems, this station is a relocation, over 100 miles, from the previous urban telegraph cable landing in Vladivostok. Similarly, the Trans-Siberian railway’s eastern terminus was shifted to Nakhodka in the 1950s, when Soviet authorities closed Vladivostok to foreign shipping. Then the only open port in the Russian Far East, Nakhodka grew rapidly from its trade and communications industries. Today, the small city of 150,000 still supports circulations across the ocean: shipping and receiving, fish processing and canning, oil, and cable signals.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/bibliographicCi.value: Wikipedia contributors, “Nakhodka,” Wikipedia, The Free Encyclopedia, accessed June 9, 2013, http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nakhodka.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: The Japan-Siberia Cable (JASC), laid in 1969, was a true postwar international collaboration. The cable was manufactured in part by Japan's Ocean Cable Company and in part by the United States's Underseas Cable Corporation (all of whose previous cables had been supplied to the US military). The cable was then laid by both the Japanese ship KDD Maru with assistance from the Dutch Great Northern Telegraph Company. This kind of collaboration was a hallmark of the analogue era. It operated long beyond its system design life (which was only 20 years) up until 1996, when it was withdrawn from service and used for earthquake research,

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: When the cable was landed in 1900, Wei-hai-wei was a British colony. On the northeastern edge of the Shandong Peninsula, the port town connected easily to Tschifu, just across the bay. Although they kept it an active port, the British never built up Wei-Hai-Wei as they did other nearby cities such as Shanghai. This was especially true after the Russo-Japanese War, when the Shandong Province was primarily controlled by Germany. Throughout the telegraph era, Wei-Hai-Wei remained a quiet harbor with small, traditional Chinese stone houses, dirt roads, canals, a cricket pitch, and parade grounds. The British military even built a sanatorium here, praising the location’s “temperate” and “healthy” climate.

Surfacing at Whitford Beach, you are careful not to be hit by one of the sixteen-foot tall waves also making its way to the shore. This beach is beautiful and active: the hollow and powerful waves draw surfers from throughout the area and the soft sands bring visitors to lounge, fly kites, and ride horses along this sunny stretch of land. Several major international cables have also landed here, connecting Australia to Asia. About ten miles inland is the Perth International Telecommunications Centre (PITC), which occupies 710 square acres of flat, dry land in a rural suburb. Since 1986, the center has handled much of Australia's signal traffic. With its own power plant, and a 15-meter diameter antenna for communicating with spacecrafts, PITC is a stark contrast to the brick house on the shores of Cottesloe that welcomed the trans-Indian-Ocean telegraph cable in 1901.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: Today, Wakkanai is the northernmost city in Japan, with one of the island’s colder climates and record snowfalls totaling over 250 inches in a year. Yet a century ago the Japanese empire stretched even further north to the 50th parallel on the island of Sakhalin, taken from the Russians during the Russo-Japanese war. Wakkanai was a strategic outpost connecting the two islands and a submarine cable was laid to carry communications between their shores. After the Russians took back Sakhalin during World War II, forcing refugees south into Wakkanai, the city remained a strategic site. The United States’ Wakkanai Air Station, established shortly after the war, used radar installations to gather intelligence during the Cold War. Only miles from Sakhalin, and not far from the border between Russia and China, the listening post amassed information about critical events in the region for decades, pre-figuring the covert collection of data today by the National Security Agency and others.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: Along the shores of the Pearl River, across from Hong Kong, Macau was a fishing village until Portuguese traders, seeking a place to dry and store goods, established themselves there in the mid 16th century. Portuguese shacks gradually grew into a settlement, but much of the area remained governed by and inhabited by the Chinese. It was not until after the opium wars of the 19th century that China ceded the right of governance and occupation to Portugal in exchange for a promise that Portugal would help Hong Kong with trade and import taxes. Shortly thereafter, in 1884, a telegraph cable connected the two cities. The city remained a Portuguese colony until 1999, making it the last remaining European colony in Asia. That year, it was both transferred back to China, and linked via modern cable technology, SEA-WE-ME-3, which revived the earlier connection to Hong Kong.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: Menado derives from the word manadou or wanazou, meaning “on the far coast” or “in the distance.” The town is located on the far northwestern tip of the Indonesian island North Sulawesi. The Dutch East India Company built a fortress here in 1658 and from that time it was slowly and steadily colonized and Christianized by traders and missionaries. The thick stone walls of the city’s fort still exist, but outside it, the town has grown into a colonial village with hedgerows, streets, gardens, and cottages. In 1905, traveling via Menado’s first undersea cable, you traverse a busy port filled with large trading vessels and smaller, slimmer pinisiq, Indonesian sailboats. The beautiful bay actually makes a bad harbor: the reefs and steep slope in the sea floor make it difficult to anchor. Between the cable landing and the distant mountaintops, expansive coffee plantations have developed. Although it will never grow into a sizeable port city, this location will remain important to the Dutch in part due to its massive coffee exports.

Covering roughly 650 miles, the cable was deployed by sister ships Restorer and Patrol, launched from England that year and sold for scrap to the Japanese only a decade later.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: “The view of the harbor in clear weather is beautiful and animated,” notes an 1897 travel guide to Surabaya. Under Dutch rule since 1743, it was the main commercial port and largest Dutch naval base in the East Indies. “On the water and along the quays great bustle prevails. . . . Chinese and Javanese, Europeans and Arabs, citizens and soldiers mingle” in the crowded streets. The arrival of two Dutch submarine cables in 1913 and 1921 brought the city into further contact with other settlements in the region. But Surabaya’s growth and vibrancy was interrupted by conflict in the 1940s. The city was captured by the Japanese and bombed by Allied forces in the Second World War. And in the 1945 Battle of Surabaya, Indonesian soldiers fought British troops for national independence. This history of profound struggle resonates with the name Surabaya, which some say derives from a mythical battle between two powerful creatures, a “sura” (shark) and a “baya” (crocodile).

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.value: On AtlanticCable.com, many landings indicated by "Mogi, Nagasaki-ken, Japan"

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: Like many port cities in Asia, Nagasaki was “discovered” by imperial powers – in this case, the Portuguese – and developed for trade. In the nineteenth century, Nagasaki became a busy transit point, with a vibrant ship-building industry, an anchorage site for the Japanese navy, and a telegraph cable landing point. Three years after its first submarine telegraph cable was landed in 1871, the telegraph company established a headquarters here, in a large two-story office building abutting the harbor. Within a few years, Japan would build up its internal landlines, and the country would be connected to the rest of the world via Nagasaki. The importance of this station was clear to Japan and its enemies. Described as “clutching the aeortic artery of international communications in Japan,” Nagasaki, as a hub and military harbor, was also a target. The cable to Vladivostok was taken out of service during the Russo-Japanese War, but the city remained undamaged. During World War II, however, Nagasaki was hit with the atomic bomb, the second and last to ever be deployed, killing several hundred thousand people. After the Japanese surrender, the city would slowly rebuild. Old communications lines were taken out of service, and new coaxial cables laid in their place.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: At the request of the Japanese government, the Great Northern Telegraph Company laid the first cable under the Korean Strait in 1883. The cable linked Nagasaki via Japan’s Tsushima Island to Pusan (now officially spelled Busan), the first international port in Korea and a major Japanese settlement.

If you could climb up the deep green mountains on the northern end of this island, and look west across the water, you would see the hills of the Korean peninsula rising above Pusan. A small island, about 700 square kilometers of land, Tsushima is equidistant between the Japanese mainland and Korea. Because of its location, it had been a trade center for centuries before the cables arrived, and since has been a perfect locale for international cable connections as well as a strategic military node. Five different cables have landed here since 1891. In 1905, during the Russo-Japanese War, a decisive battle was fought in the waters around the island, which the Japanese won largely through their adeptness with wireless telegraphy. Yet this did not lead to the scrapping of “older” cable systems. Quite the opposite. After the war, the Japanese immediately laid a new undersea telegraph cable: wires complement, rather than replace, wireless.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: When it was completed in December 1937, the submarine cable between Fukuoka and Pusan became part of the longest carrier telephone line in service. From Fukuoka, the six-channel cable ran over the Japanese mainland to Tokyo, and from Pusan, it extended north through Korea and into the Manchukuo region of China, covering a total of more than 2,000 miles. The cable not only improved the quality of commercial telephone calls between Japan and the continent, but also expanded Japanese military communications in the lead-up to the Second World War.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: Originally named Yangon in the 1700s, “end of strife” in Burmese, the city’s name was perverted under British colonial rule a century later. At the convergence of two major rivers, Rangoon is about 30 kilometers inland from the Gulf of Martaban. In 1877, the British laid a cable across the Andaman Sea, connecting Rangoon to nearby Penang. As it was built up into a colonial political center and commercial hub, the rivers served as excellent trade routes. An army engineer was enlisted to design a gridded, western-style city. When the cable arrived, Rangoon boasted sprawling parks, wealthy suburbs, lakes, hospitals, and a mix of colonial and traditional architecture. The telegraph office was established in a large, four story red brick building with ionic columns marking the entrance. Although the British rule disappeared in 1948, following great strife and a protracted struggle for independence, this building still stands today. Myanmar's first and, as of 2014, only fiber-optic link, lands about 75 miles south in coastal Pyapon. The country's inclusion in this system also depended on external support, as in the colonial era, it is only one small stop in a globe-spanning network.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: In the early 1890s, a telegraph cable was brought to Medan, part of the rapid growth and industrialization the area had been experiencing over the past 50 years. In the 1820s it was a small village of 200 people, but with the development of tobacco plantations by Dutch colonists in the 1860s, the village quickly grew into a modern city. By 1910, it had population of 17,500. The cable arrived in the midst of this development: the port area bustled with trading ships and Chinese and Javanese laborers brought in to work in the tobacco industry.  The center of town was being built up to serve the Dutch businessmen: a post office, social club, city hall, and street cafes all were emerging, in colonial European architectural style. Grand stone buildings with pillars and arched windows and Germanic houses with red roofs lined the street where the cable station was built, just past a traditional Chinese archway that marked the entrance to the town.

As you approach Colombo, Ceylon (present-day Sri Lanka) in 1903, your travel guide tells you: “its appearance is extremely picturesque: a fine undulating country, well wooded to the water’s edge and fringed by cocoa-nut trees; lofty verdant ranges tower in the distance, covered with groves of talipat and other palms.” Centrally positioned in the Indian Ocean, Colombo was a key trade port long before the colonial era. In the early 1500s, the Portuguese established a fort and trading post to capitalize on the island’s abundant cinnamon crops. After a brief Dutch occupation, Colombo was ceded to the British and became the capital of British Ceylon. To facilitate faster communication to London, a submarine cable was brought to the island via the Middle East in 1913, connecting to a new Central Telegraph Office in a three-story wood building near the harbor. Messages could now travel between the two cities in as little as thirty minutes, a savings of nearly four hours compared to older land-based routes through India. Today, messages transit in only milliseconds from five cable systems that land in the Colombo area.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: Remains of stone-age cultures have been found in Fuzhou, dating back to 5000 B.C.E. Over the millennia, many civilizations have arisen and fallen on this land. In the 10th century, tall pagodas were erected to protect the city from “evil influences of atmospheric currents.” Such currents brought human trouble more than atmospheric calamity, as the site became desirable to foreign imperial powers. The waterways that run along the city make it ideal for trading and transportation, while the rich, wet earth cultivates rice fields, and the nearby island-protected harbors provide good anchor for military and trade ships. By the 19th century, Fuzhou had grown into a large walled city with a population of over half a million. Westerners ran major trade operations from the city following the British victory in the first Opium War, which opened the port – then called Foochow – to foreign trade. More recently, the area has been opened to foreign circulations in another way: Fuzhou has been declared a free trade zone, and a new fiber-optic cable lands there linking to Taiwan. As goods and signals flow in and out freely, the economy has become less stable. Fuzhou is now known for supplying America with a labor force, as young adults from its suburbs come to the United States to work long hours at low wages.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: You might have come here in 1871, when the China Submarine Telegraph Cable company surfaced a cable from Singapore. Or, you might have come along the 1884 cable, brought ashore by the Eastern Extension company. Despite these outlets to British Empire, the city remained in the hands of the French, who did not lay their own cable until the turn of the twentieth century. It was the French colony of Cochinchina and as a port, a city, and a communications hub, became militarily, economically, and ideologically important for the following century. Indigenous rebel forces regularly fought bloody battles against colonization, as the French and Japanese squabbled over the city until its independence in 1954. During the Vietnam War, the U.S. and other western nations would back forces originating from Saigon in their fight against communist North Vietnam. Leaving the city during these years, transmission was slow: the government controlled the cable station and any international messages were delayed for at least an hour in order for the censors to approve them before they could be sent through the system.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: The French post and telegraph service extended a system between their island of Poulo Condor, off the coast of French Indochina, and Pontianak in the Dutch East Indies in 1906.

“The little village of Donggala, capital of the ‘kingdom of Palos,’ as it is called in books, lies most picturesquely at the foot of the green chalk rocks along the narrow beach,” notes a guide to the Dutch East Indies from 1897. In the early 1900s, Donggala flourished as the principle harbor for the Bay of Palos (now known as the Bay of Palu) in Central Sulawesi. Coffee and coconuts grown in the surrounding hills were exported in large quantities, and various goods were traded by sea and land. A Dutch cable arrived in 1921 linking the town to area settlements. During the Second World War, however, Palu became the provincial capital and trade flows shifted south. As a result, Donggala is still the small and picturesque seaport it was at the turn of the century.

On the shore at Mon Repos, a group of sea turtle hatchlings makes their way across the sandy beach and into the ocean. Long before this beach became a conservation park for the now endangered turtles, the site was a landing for a French telegraph cable. It was a short-lived system, connecting the nearby municipality of Bundaberg with the French colony of New Caledonia. At that time, Bundaberg and its environs were hardly developed. The area was populated by a small group of European timbergetters and farmers, and an established indigenous population of Kabi people, from whose language the city derives its name. A sawmill was built along the municipality’s river in 1868, drawing surveyors and settlers, and a sugar mill was built in 1882, around which a successful industry grew. This small, industrial, mostly British town had little interest in New Caledonia, a French colony known mostly for its political prisoners and fledgling mining industry.

In 1917, following a fire at their cable station on New Zealand’s South Island, the Eastern Extension company re-located their links to Titahi Bay, on the North Island. The nature of the company and the culture of the station changed with this move. There was no need to physically man the coastal cable house. Here, the circuits were automatically switched once they came ashore and messages were routed directly to Wellington. Cable work no longer took place in a rural outpost, but the Eastern Extension’s office in the center of the city. On one hand, given the World War unfolding at the time, this shift to a population hub seemed to make the cable more secure. But on the other hand, along with automatic transmission, it drastically changed the culture of tight-knit cable operators.

Dairen, Manchuria is today’s Dalian, China. This port city sits on a peninsula that juts out into the Yellow Sea, bisecting the Chinese mainland and North Korea, and threading together the region’s histories of communications and transport. At the time of its first cable landing, this piece of land was under Russian control. Valued in part because of its southern location, the port gave the Russians year-round access to the Pacific. During their occupation, the Russians gradually transformed Dairen from a small fishing village to a busy naval and shipping harbor, where small wooden warehouses, cranes, and a railroad lined the water. When the Russo-Japanese War broke out in 1904, the Japanese quickly took control of the port and brought in a telegraph cable. In 1908, a new cable linked the city to China, but accepted messages only in Japanese outside certain portions of the day. Eventually the city was transferred back to the Russians, and finally to the Chinese government in 1950.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: The Japanese Government laid this system in 1904, in line with their expanding territorial ambitions at the turn of the twentieth century.

Although it started out as a small farm town, Shanghai grew into an important and busy port during the Qing Dynasty. In 1842, after the British defeated the Chinese in the first Opium War, Shanghai became a treaty port, occupied by British forces and open for international trade. Throughout the end of the 19th and beginning of the 20th centuries, the city grew rapidly. Tall municipal buildings and three-story stone houses with red roofs lined the wide and busy streets. The ports were congested with naval and trade ships from Britain, France, and Japan. The first telegraph cable arrived in 1871, connecting the city to Singapore and Hong Kong. As the cable was laid up the Yangtze River to Shanghai, men armed with rifles patrolled it to stop sailors from throwing anchor and severing the connection. By 1916, ten more cables - sponsored by a range of governments and militaries - had landed here, linking to Japan, Russia, Yap, the Philippines, and other Chinese ports.

This final link extended the Commercial Pacific Cable Company's network from Manila to Shanghai in 1906. On July 4th, United States President Theodore Roosevelt and the president of the Commercial Pacific Cable Company, Clarence Mackay, exchanged messages that telegraphically encircled the globe.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: A tiny island off the northeastern coast of Malaysia, Labuan was the site of important British coal fields during the colonial era. Nestled safely within the Brunei Bay, the spot was ideal for the traffic of signals, ships, and resources. Labuan became a stopping point for the cable connecting Singapore and Hong Kong, which it existing midway between, in 1894. British ships also stopped here as they traversed the South China Sea: the harvesting of coal made it both an export center and a fueling point for the Imperial Navy. This flat, green island remained relatively unsettled by the British, who used it almost exclusively for its ore and harbor. Today, the island’s development continues to depend on its ocean-going history. Scuba divers come here to explore old sunken ships and oil and gas companies drill offshore, harvesting modern energy sources.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/bibliographicCi.value: Bill Glover, “Cable Timeline: 1845-1900,” History of the Atlantic Cable & Undersea Communications: from the first submarine cable of 1850 to the worldwide fiber optic network, accessed August 12, 2013, http://atlantic-cable.com/Cables/CableTimeLine/index1850.htm.
Commander of the Guard Ship, Ed. S. T., “Labuan – Coal Discoveries,” Hongkong Register, April 27, 1847, accessed August 12, 2013, http://trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/31752854.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: The island of Billiton (the old Dutch spelling of Belitung) was a valuable site of tin extraction in the colonial era. Dutch mining operations started in the mid-1800s with the formation of the Billiton Company, named after the island. The company imported thousands of Chinese indentured laborers to perform the heavy and dangerous work in the mines. In the early 1900s, the Dutch East Indies government brought two submarine cables to Billiton’s capital city of Tanjung Pandan, connecting it to colonies in Java, Borneo, and Sumatra. Only a decade later, however, the capital was looted and set ablaze in a worker’s revolt. Belitung and the neighboring island of Bangka are still key points in the global tin trade. The Guardian estimates that in 2012 they produced 90% of the tin in Indonesia, an extraordinary amount given that Indonesia is the second-largest producer of the metal in the world.

In Malay and Indonesian mythology, the pontianak is a vampiric ghost, the spirit of a woman who dies while pregnant. The town of Pontianak is named after one such woman, said to have haunted the first Sultan who ruled the area. Founded in 1771 on swampy ground near an old coastal trading station, Pontianak is watery, foggy, and not entirely terrestrial. The early settlement became a center of piratical activity as well as a port for the Dutch East Indies Company. In the 19th century the land officially became a protectorate of the Dutch East Indies. As the port grew in size it was built mostly on stilts due to the swampy land. At the turn of the 20th century, it was the French, however, not the Dutch, who laid an undersea cable to the site, connecting to French Indochina. It was not until a century later, in 2006, that the next cable landed here, a fiber-optic one linking out to Batam and Jakarta.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: The small fishing village of Budai, Taiwan (known as Hotei in Japanese) played an important role in Japan’s conquest of Taiwan due to its proximity to the Penghu Islands. On the morning of October 10, 1895, Japanese military forces departed from their base on Penghu and sailed to Budai. From there, they moved south to encircle the capital city of Tainan. This connection was retraced more than two decades later by an undersea cable between Budai and Penghu, part of the expansion of Taiwan’s telegraph network under Japanese rule. In addition to its ties to military and communications networks, Budai was a regional hub of salt production in the early twentieth century. The city’s seawater evaporation plant employed several hundred workers and produced roughly eighteen million pounds of salt per year.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/bibliographicCi.value:

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: Heading inland to the Makaha cable station, you surface in a parking lot, in a manhole barely visible under the dirt. Along the beaches to the south of this town reside hundreds of houseless people. O‘ahu’s west shore is home to one of the state’s largest native communities and largest homeless population. In Makaha alone, 32% of its residents live in poverty. Yet, the west shore is also a transit point for a large percentage of the state’s international signal traffic. Since the 1960s, almost all of the island’s coaxial and fiber-optic cables have terminated at three cable stations along this short 30-kilometer stretch. The seemingly divergent histories of telecommunications success and economic deprivation in the area are intertwined, linked to the area's long-standing military occupation. Weapons testing sites and military installations, such as the Lualualei Naval Reservation and the Schofield Barracks, displaced residents from the west shore’s inland valleys. At the same time, the U.S. military was once one of the biggest customers of the cable networks, giving them both an economic boost and a layer of protection when they were set up during the Cold War.

Haiphong was founded in the year 43 B.C.E. by Lê Chân, a female general of a Vietnamese revolutionary army. In response to increasing Chinese expansion and mistreatment, two sisters from a military family in a rural Vietnamese village overthrew their Chinese overlords, and formed this small, mostly-female army. From here, the Trưng Sisters’ forces expanded southwards and they liberated Vietnam within a matter of months. Haiphong was an important strategic site. The city’s name means “defensive coastal area.” The area’s deep harbor and location at the mouth of Cấm River had made it an important port and naval base throughout history. The Trung rule only lasted three years, after which the Vietnamese would again struggle against Chinese domination until French colonialism overpowered both Chinese and indigenous movements. Haiphong, given its strategic location, then became the center of French naval operations. When France began the project of connecting its colonies via telegraph cables, Haiphong became an important landing site, a stopping point for signals between Saigon and Amoy. In Vietnam today, the leaders of the ancient revolutionary uprising remain national heroes, and an imposing statue of Lê Chân now stands watch over Haiphong’s waterways.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/bibliographicCi.value: Bill Glover, “French PTT,” History of the Atlantic Cable & Undersea Communications: from the first submarine cable of 1850 to the worldwide fiber optic network, accessed August 14, 2013, http://atlantic-cable.com/CableCos/France/ptt.htm.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: From a mostly undeveloped beach several miles north of Miyazaki, you follow a dirt path inland until it opens onto a single-lane road. In the distance, a ringed communications tower is visible above the treetops. Homing in on this beacon, you reach a windowless building surrounded on all sides by a barbed-wire fence. Three majestic palm trees and a plaque bearing the logo of Japanese telecom company KDDI mark the entrance, while farmland and greenhouses occupy the surrounding plots. In 1977, the first telephone cable arrived from Okinawa, where a trans-Pacific link to the U.S. had recently been completed. Optical cables followed in the 1990s, but more recent connections have overlooked Miyazaki in favor of the cluster of hubs along the east coast of Honshu Island.

The Okinawa Prefecture encompasses a string of small islands, about 300 miles south of the rest of Japan and only 200 miles northeast of Taiwan. Geographically and politically separated from the other Japanese islands, the Okinawan islands remained more or less self-governing until the Meiji Restoration, when they became a target for Japan's expansionist aims. After winning the Sino-Japanese War in 1895, Japan immediately began laying cables connecting its territories, including one between Okinawa and the other prefectures. More importantly, in 1897, a cable was laid that connected Okinawa Island to Taiwan, allowing international telegraph communications to and from Japan and its colonial holdings. For this endeavor, Japan even built its own cable ship, the Okinawa Maru. Not long afterward, during the Russo-Japanese War, the Japanese used the ship to cut the telegraph cable connecting Yap and Shanghai. They then retrieved the cable and connected Yap to Okinawa instead.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: Tschifu is today called Yantai, meaning “smoky tower.” In a way, this harbor town was always a critical communications node: the name refers back to the Ming Dynasty, when locals would light smoky fires to warn the village of approaching Japanese pirates. On the north-eastern tip of the Shandong Peninsula, Tschifu was directly south of Dairen, due west of Seoul, and straight north from Shanghai. Its central location made it an ideal cable hub during the telegraph era. In the first decade of the twentieth century, ten cables were landed here, connecting to Tsingtau, Port Arthur, Taku, Dairen, Shanghai, and Wei-hai-wei. Even before the cables were landed, the city had long been an important traffic hub: it had been an international trading port for almost half a century and seventeen nations had established embassies there.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: The Russian post and telegraph service laid this cable from Port Arthur to Tschifu. Only five years later, the cable was handed over to the Imperial Chinese Telegraph Company. Subsequently, Japan signed a treaty with China to operate the system.

Midway between Taiwan and China, this chain of small islands is strategically important. As a result, even though the islands are sparsely populated, they have long been connected by communications networks. In 1887, the government landed a cable here, connecting to China on one side and to the rest of Taiwan on the other. Less than ten years later, the Chinese attacked and attempted to take possession of the islands, but were driven away by the Japanese, who were then occupying Penghu and later, all of Taiwan. The Japanese would remain in Penghu throughout the first half of the twentieth century, laying cables that linked China and Taiwan. While the connected cities grew busy with international trade, the Penghu Islands remained apart from the action, with most ships and signal traffic merely passing through.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: Situated in an office park, the Alexandria cable station is just a few hundred feet from the Alexandra Canal, built in the late nineteenth century to provide barge access to South Sydney. By the 1940s, Alexandria had more than five hundred factories producing bricks, wool fabrics, airplane parts, and other goods, as well as a branch of the Standard Telephones and Cables Company. Set up to provide voice links to Britain in the early twentieth century, Standard went on to manufacture underwater cables, including one between Sydney and Vancouver in the 1980s. Despite its proximity to the station, cables don’t surface in the canal, now widely considered the most polluted waterway in Australia. Instead, lines from the Southern Cross system arrive near the historical cable landing at Bondi Beach before heading inland to Alexandria. Here, connections are made to several nearby data centers, drawn to the area by the presence of the cable head.

Founded in the fifteenth century by Muslim sultans, Aceh (then Kutaraja or “City of the King”) was a prosperous trade port – it delivered over half the world’s pepper supply in the 1820s. Yet the city’s status as a commercial hub is overshadowed by a history of war and natural disaster. Between 1873 and 1903, the Dutch fought local Acehnese forces for control of Northern Sumatra. In the midst of the long and bloody conflict, Dutch ships laid a cable to their settlement in Medan to aid military communications. A century later, an earthquake struck off the west coast of Aceh, causing a devastating tsunami that killed tens of thousands and leveled large swaths of the city. Although there were no warning systems in place in 2004, new research suggests that undersea cables could one day be used to track the waves and signal evacuations.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/bibliographicCi.value:

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: Huế is a watery city. Located in the center of the Vietnamese coast, its harbors and lagoons are protected by narrow strips of land that separate them from the South China Sea. The flat, grey-green Perfume River winds inland for a few miles, where it meets a matrix of canals flowing through the heart of the city. In the 17th century, the Nguyen Lords established the seat of their empire here, in a closed citadel on the north side of the river, from which they governed most of southern Vietnam. Everywhere there are monuments to the city’s prominence throughout the centuries: old tombs of emperors, ancient grey stone gates, carved statues, and brightly colored pagodas. At the beginning of the 1800s, Huế was captured by Emperor Gia Long and made capital of all of Vietnam. It was not until the city became a “French protectorate,” later in the 19th century, that it was linked by its first undersea cable.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: Mukilteo, a Native-American name that has come to mean “good camping ground,” has long been a staging ground for circulation and exchange. It was in Mukilteo that 82 Native American leaders signed over large swathes of land to white settlers in the famous Port Elliot Treaty. And as Americans migrated westward, enterprises such as the Puget Mill Lumber Company cleared the land for them, shipping the region’s trees to ports around the world, as far away as Shanghai and Cape Town. Harbour Pointe, a part of Mukilteo once owned by a logging company, was sold to Standard Oil, which planned to use the land for a refinery. Although this plan never materialized, in the 1960s the company put forward a proposal for “Possession Shores,” a master-planned community that would provide, among other things, housing for workers in the world’s largest factory: Boeing’s airplane assembly lot, only a few miles away. After decades, the master-plan has been at least partially realized. The town has upscale homes, an expansive golf course, technology parks, and two undersea cable systems which bridge Harbour Pointe to Alaska, California, and Japan.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/rightsHolder.value: NTT

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: Arriving from the Southern Cross Cable Network, you surface on Narrabeen Beach, unhindered by fishing nets, boat anchors, or dredging equipment. These activities are prohibited in this government-sanctioned cable protection area, one of two established in Sydney in 2005. Once ashore, you travel four miles south to Brookvale, which has been a commercial and industrial center in North Sydney since the 1950s. The station blends in with surrounding businesses: sign printers, auto body shops, and several well-known surfboard manufacturers. As dents are repaired and signals enter local networks, many of the boards crafted in Brookvale end up back in the waves off Narrabeen Beach where volunteer lifeguards operate out of local surf clubs. This safe-zone for surfers and cables is the only Australian site mentioned in the 1963 Beach Boys hit “Surfin’ U.S.A.”

Muntok is a young city by Indonesian standards – it was founded in 1732 by an order of the Sultan Palembang Darussalam, and at that time consisted of only seven wooden houses. When the cable landed in 1859, Muntok was still a small town, now comprised of red-roofed houses clustered around a bay. Tall, straight palm trees lined the empty dirt roads. The engineer who installed the cable wrote of Muntok: “All serene. Great trouble with the telegraphists … who sleep on duty, and otherwise keep Siemens constantly in the station.” The little village woke up over the following decades as the Dutch built houses and canals, using the town as a communications node and a site for exporting indigenous goods. Then, as now, the area was rich in tin, and the harvesting, smelting and exporting of the ore put Muntok on the map for colonial trade. The cables have gone, however, and it remains a quiet smelting and mining spot, an offshoot to the larger and more central Palembang.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: On some islands, even finding a shore on which to land one’s cable is a fraught process. Located about 1000 miles south east of Japan, the Bonin Islands have steep coastlines that make landing difficult. Rocky mountainsides rise up from the blue-green sea, gradually turning from stone into lush greenery higher in the sky. In some spots, small strips of sand slice between the ocean and the hills. In the early 1900s, a cable landed on one of these remote beaches, connecting Guam (and thereby the United States) to Japan. The Japanese had claimed the land only a few decades earlier, and about forty settlers made their homes on the previously uninhabited islands. The American company sent British ships and workers here to land the cable, all of whom were tentatively but amicably received. Like the small beaches that marry the water and land, the islands served as the tiny but essential solder point between the US and Japan, mediating communication between these two distant societies.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: Completed in early 1906, the Yokohama-Bonin cable was part of a system linking Japan and the United States, with stopovers on several Pacific islands. As the journal Telegraph Age reports that year: “Bonin has recently been connected to Yokohama by a cable of English manufacture which the Japanese government has been laying with its own cable-ship, the Okinawa Maru. . . . The work was finished in twelve days without the least hitch, and the signals through the cable when laid were excellent.”

The port of Yokohama was a modest fishing village until the 1850s, when it was opened to foreign trade under pressure from the U.S.. Rapid development followed, transforming Yokohama into an international center of commerce. Japan’s first overland telegraph line linked Yokohama’s Court House station with neighboring Tokyo in 1869. Thirty-five years later, a submarine cable arrived from the Bonin Islands, bringing the city into communication with San Francisco more than 5,000 miles away. But the Great Kantō earthquake of 1923 devastated the city, including its nascent cable infrastructure. As a local newspaper reports, a tsunami swallowed boats in the harbor, fires swept through the streets, and “the telegraph building, in which most of the wires radiating to all parts of the island terminated, was completely demolished, leaving the telegraph system in a hopeless condition.” Yokohama was soon rebuilt, only to suffer more damage during the air raids of World War II.

Undiscovered until the 1500s, no humans had ever lived on this tiny, untouched tropical island off the east coast of Madagascar. But by the early 1900s, Mauritius was one of the most connected places on the planet. The British took control of this island after the Napoleonic Wars and began farming sugar cane here, using indentured laborers from India. The cable came shortly thereafter, making Mauritius a stopping point between South Africa and Asia. The workers who came here, whether to raise cane or transmit signals, might have felt like they landed in Eden: the land is lush and bright green, with steep mountains rising above rolling fields. The world’s third largest coral reef surrounds the island, protecting the lagoons, where the water is so clear and clean that you can see right through it. Today, the island is still remote and protected, yet connected. Two major fiber-optic networks run cables to either end of the landmass,  which recently was ranked as having some of the freshest air in the world. Strange animals survive everywhere: brightly colored Geckos crawl along branches, monkeys swing from the trees, and wild pigs rustle in the underbrush.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: The only station on the west coast of Honshu, Naoetsu was linked to Russia by coaxial cable in 1969, followed by optical lines in the 1990s and 2000s. But this was not the town’s first entry into exchange networks. As early as the ninth century, its harbor bustled with merchant ships carrying rice, salted salmon, and fabrics for protection against the wet and snowy climate, later expanding to accommodate steamships and cargo vessels. Naoetsu is also the birthplace of Maejima Hisoka, Japan’s first Minister of Communications and so-called father of the postal system. After studying British mail delivery in 1870, he returned to Japan and set up a network of sixty-five offices between Tokyo and Osaka. By 1881, there were more than five thousand.

An oil boom in the early 1900s transformed Balikpapan from a small fishing village into a center of petroleum production. It became the regional headquarters of the Bataafsche Petroleum Company in 1907, and tankers carrying petrol and paraffin wax soon filled the harbor. Balikpapan’s industrial success spurred investment in roads, buildings, and communications: this included three undersea cables set up by the Dutch East Indies Government and a high-powered wireless telegraph station that could transmit signals hundreds of miles to other colonial settlements. Cable and wireless telegraphy proved invaluable for coordinating petroleum shipping in the area. Oil merchants, explains a 1914 article, “call first at Balikpapan or at some other port in telegraphic communication with Balikpapan so that the latter is always advised by telegraph of the prospective sailings and calls and requirements of these tank boats.”

The Deep Water Bay cable station is situated on one of the most expensive properties in our undersea network. Overlooking a small bay on Hong Kong’s south shore, the station was built when there was little development in the area. Today, it is the oldest still operational station on the island and has been the connection point for numerous cables since the 1960s. In the intervening years, Hong Kong’s affluent residents migrated to the nearby hills and the area’s forest was replaced with mansions. Unlike the typical windowless structures that populate the cable system, Deep Water Bay’s postwar architecture offers a lookout onto the beaches and ocean below. Peering out of the station windows, you have a better view of the bay than Hong Kong’s richest man. There are few people here to enjoy it, however: since it opened, machines have replaced many of the workers.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: Malacca was an ancient fishing village before it was taken over by the Portuguese in the 1500s, followed by the Dutch and the British. When first telegraph cable arrived in 1879, the port city had both native and colonial populations, and each responded differently to the new technology. According to the British news report from Malacca, the local Malays avoided the cable house after dark, “even now when they see [that] no demon is concealed in the coil of wire.” For Malacca’s European inhabitants, however, the telegraph link was more mundane than mysterious. “One would have thought,” the article laments, “that the laying of the cable would have brought us more into communication with Singapore . . . that the wants of our little Settlement and more news about us would have appeared in the Journals but such is not the case.” Although the settlers did not feel fully connected, the cable had at least one practical benefit: “we get the time more exact than we used to.”

Landing at Ela Beach, it’s hard to believe you are in one of the most dangerous places in the Pacific. Blue-green waters lap up against the white sands, strewn with seaweed. Papuan children splash in the water and linger under palm trees. Traveling a bit farther up the coast, past a cargo terminal, to the Poreporena Villages, you find an entire shanty-town built on rotting stilts. The water here is less clear and the rocky beach is strewn with trash. Port Moresby, the capital city of Papua New Guinea, is riddled with poverty. Raskol gangs, known for armed robberies, roam the streets and clash with the police, who have an equally violent reputation. The murder rate in this city of 250,000 is three times that of London. Just across the Coral Sea from Australia, the city has been the entry way for Papua New Guinea’s cable communications since 1976 – an infrastructure that many had hoped would contribute to development and better lives for the country’s citizens.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: Famous for its fortifications more than its receptiveness, Taku has been a critical gateway to China since the 1500s. It is just downriver from the busy trading city of Tianjin, where the Hai connects to the Yellow and Yangtze rivers, and boats filled with goods have traveled for centuries. The water that connects Taku also made it vulnerable. To protect against Japanese pirates, the Chinese erected forts here in the 16th century. During the Opium Wars of the 19th century, these forts were expanded in response to concerns about Western imperial invasion. The concerns were valid: in 1858 the British won a battle here which opened the port to foreigners, allowing foreign legations, Christian missionaries, and the legal import of opium. The site remained highly contested for the rest of the century. In 1900, the Chinese government commissioned both the Great Northern Telegraph Company and the Eastern Extension Telegraph Company to lay cables to Taku. Things were tense: signals were often intercepted, foreign boats lurked in the harbor, Chinese troops filled the forts, and almost 2400 Russian soldiers were stationed in Tianjin. In June of that year, as the Boxer Rebellion erupted in Beijing, the occupying western nations collaboratively and successfully attacked the Taku Forts in a violent battle, leaving the area awash in “rivers of blood.” As was the case in many locales, cables followed conflict, and a month later, a German company began the construction on its own telegraph to Taku.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: Although it was a landing site in the 1997 Asia-Pacific Cable Network, Chao Samran, Phetchaburi never grew into a true cable hub. Later connections favored stations in the south, closer to Malaysia, Singapore, and Indonesia, or the economically dominant Satun across the Gulf of Thailand. A similar shift occurred a hundred years ago during the reign of King Rama VI. In 1918, the king built a royal summer residence on the shores of Phetchaburi province, renamed Hat Chao Samran or “Royal Leisure Beach.” For a few years, Chao Samran was a popular vacation spot among elites. But poor transportation and a lack of fresh water eventually led the king to demolish the residence and rebuild it further south where resources were more plentiful.

“CABLE SITUATION AT AMOY. MUCH DISCONTENT” reads the headline in a 1931 Singapore newspaper. “The prosperity of business in Amoy largely depends upon its rapid communications by cable to the South Seas,” the article explains, but telegrams “intended for Amoy are now relayed to Shanghai.” Service was disrupted when, a few days prior, Chinese officials shut down the Great Northern Telegraph Company office on Kulangsu Island, where a Danish cable stopped on its way from Hong Kong and Shanghai. This cable originally bypassed Amoy, but in 1873, the company added a branch to the city without Chinese permission and began profiting from the added traffic. When China took control of the Kulangsu-Amoy connection in 1931, it disrupted local businesses already heavily reliant on submarine telegraphy.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: In 1902, as part of a wave of strategically and nationally driven cables in the early twentieth century, the French post and telegraph service laid a system between Tourane, in French Indochina, to Amoy, China.

In 1887, a cable was laid from Anping harbor in Tainan, then the capital of Taiwan, to the Penghu archipelago on the order of Liu Mingchuan, an official in the Qing dynasty. The lack of trade between Tainan and Penghu meant that the cable “was of little importance to the commercial world,” explains American diplomat James W. Davidson. Yet “it was of great value from a political standpoint, the strategic importance of the [Penghu] islands demanding that they should be in communication with the capital.” This political value was short-lived, however, since the capital was moved north to Taipei later that year. Tainan has seen many such political fluctuations in its history. The Dutch established a fort here in the early 1600s, which was later taken over by Chinese military leaders, the Qing, the Japanese, and finally the Republic of China. Reconstituted under each new ruler, Tainen was nicknamed “The Phoenix City.”

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: Southwest of Dairen, at the tip of the Liaodong Peninsula, Port Arthur was an important Russian naval port at the turn of the twentieth century. It has a naturally protected southern harbor, allowing ships safe anchor throughout the year. In 1900, the Russians landed two telegraph cables here, one connecting south across the Yellow Sea to Tschifu, China and one connecting the longer distance west to Sasebo. This communications node would soon become Russia’s Achilles’ Heel: the cables were cut and intercepted by the Japanese leading up to and during the Russo-Japanese War.  Unable to receive reports or warnings, Port Arthur was then surprised when Japanese ships attacked. The Japanese took control of Port Arthur and from here were able to wage a successful war for the control of Manchurian land and sea. Unrest may have started even earlier, however: in the year before the war, cable ships record trips to repair breaks in the Port Arthur – Tschifu cable, due to “willful cutting.”

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: Alongside a cable to Tschifu, he Russian post and telegraph service laid a cable from Port Arthur to Sasebo, in Japan. Only five years later, both were handed over to the Imperial Chinese Telegraph Company.

You find yourself in a dark, small stone building, held by a Japanese military man. Outside, things are quiet. A road lined with palm trees leads into the dark green mountains, overlooking shallow blue-green harbors. Boats are prohibited from anchoring here because of the cable. Midway between Taiwan and the main island of Okinawa, Ishigaki has recently become essential for Japanese international and military communications. In 1897, this building has been newly built to transmit telegraph signals to Okinawa and Taiwan. In years to come, the quiet will be shattered by wars. The building will become busy with transmissions, bombed, and damaged, although not destroyed. Long after it is abandoned, some locals will sense that ghosts remain inside.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: You find yourself stuck in a building on the water, in an assemblage of similar, elegant structures. The post office, hotels, and assorted administrative buildings all are built in French colonial style, often painted yellow with white trim. Many possess balconies, large arched windows, and manicured gardens. Outside, the port of Tourane is busy with trading ships, which linger in the harbor, where the Hàn River opens into the South China Sea. Steep mountains rich in coal surround the town and farther inland, the river is lined by rice fields. With such resources have come colonial empires, and with empires, have come cables.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: “The trees obscure the houses near the beach, making it difficult to distinguish the port,” warns a British steamship captain in 1910. His description of Buleleng also notes the twin telegraph cables connecting the town to other Dutch colonies across the Bali Sea and to the nearby island province of West Nusa Teggara. In the 1840s, the Dutch performed a series of military operations in northern Bali before establishing a formal colony in Buleleng in 1882. It was their first on the island and the center of the new colonial administration. Although camouflaged by trees, the Buleleng harbor was a highly visible point on the map of international trade. By the late nineteenth century, dozens of European ships and hundreds of local vessels carrying rice, coffee, spices, vanilla, and tobacco came through the port every year.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: Sasebo became an essential node for military communications at the turn of the twentieth century. This Japanese port is about 100 miles south of the southern tip of Korea, across the ocean from Shanghai. The town had been a small fishing village until the Meiji Period, when it quickly became an important naval base because of its protected, nearly land-locked, deep harbor. In 1898, a major railway station was opened here, anticipating the other traffic to come. Cables came in from Port Arthur, and out across the East China Sea to Dairen and Tsingtau. The town grew up around the transiting traffic, becoming a busy port and a wireless station. Like many other hubs in the Pacific, its connectivity would become a liability in future years. The wireless station here is believed to have broadcasted the message to attack Pearl Harbor during World War II. Four years later, Sasebo suffered severe bombing by allied forces, and was on the list of potential targets for the dropping of the atom bomb.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: Following a link from Nagasaki to Tsingtau, the Japanese Military laid a cable between Tsingtau to Sasebo, where their Naval Base was located.

Fukuoka has been an exchange point between Japan and the rest of Asia for millennia. In the year 57, a Han Dynasty emperor bestowed a gold seal on the King of Na (present day Fukuoka). Over the following centuries, the city’s proximity to Korea and China facilitated international trade as well as the flow of Buddhism and agricultural techniques into Japan. But this proximity also made it a target: Fukuoka was attacked by Mongol fleets in the 1200s, only to be saved by well-timed typhoons or “Kamikazes” (Japanese for “divine wind”). Communication technologies only reinforced these ancient economic, cultural, and military connections. Telegraph cables linked the Kyushu region with Korea beginning in the 1880s, radiotelephone was introduced in the 1920s, and the arrival of a submarine cable in 1937 provided long-distance telephone service between Japan, Korea, and China for the first time.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/rightsHolder.value: Kyushu Electric Power,  KT,  Softbank Telecom,  NTT

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: Reihoku occupies a knob-shaped peninsula on the largest island of Amakusa, meaning “heaven’s grass” and named after its verdant, undulating terrain. Part of the underwater network only briefly, the town was linked to Nanhui by the East China Sea telephone cable between 1976 and 1997. Earlier telegraph lines to China surfaced in Nagasaki while Miyazaki received later fiber optic connections. The cable’s landing site is similarly bracketed by historical and contemporary infrastructures. On one side are the ruins of Tomioka Castle, built in the early 1600s by a feudal lord and later attacked by rebelling Christian peasants. And on the other is a modern coal-fired power station that generates most of the electricity for the surrounding Kumamoto Prefecture.

The KDDI-owned East China Sea Cable, also know as the Japan-China cable system, linked Reihoku and Nanhui in 1976. A commemorative silver coin shows a dotted line across the East China Sea, bisected by a telephone receiver emitting bolts of electricity. Its 480-voice-channel capacity was interrupted in 1980 by fishing operations and not repaired until five years later. ECSC was eventually decommissioned in 1997.

Portuguese, Spanish, and Dutch forces vied with local rulers for control of this small volcanic island, the northern gateway to the “spice islands” of Maluku and once the world’s only source of cloves. In the 1600s, the Dutch seized Ternate and began to manage trade in the region. The East India Company created a monopoly on cloves by destroying all non-Dutch plantations and making unauthorized growing punishable by death. Trade expansion necessitated faster communication channels, and in 1913 an underwater cable connected Ternate to Dutch settlements in Java and Borneo. As clove production spread elsewhere, the island became less centrally important. But a nearly 400-year-old clove tree—the oldest in the world—still stands on Ternate as evidence of its past distinctiveness.

When China began to struggle against imperialism in the late 1800s, Qingdao was an important node of resistance. The Boxers, an anti-imperialist, proto-nationalist Chinese movement, had a strong presence in area, and in 1897, the Chinese government began building up a military base here to protect against foreign invasion. Shortly thereafter, German troops seized and occupied this fort. After a year of fighting, China conceded the area to Germany, who re-named the city Tsingtau, a French transliteration of the original name. This small Chinese fishing village was transformed into a German administrative and economic center, with tall three-story stone buildings, wide streets, electricity, and a navy base. At the turn of the century, two telegraph cables were landed, one connecting to Tschifu and one to Shanghai. Today, two major cable systems continue to land at Qingdao, linking the city to Korea and across the sea to California.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/bibliographicCi.value: Bill Glover, “Cable Timeline: 1845-1900,” History of the Atlantic Cable & Undersea Communications: from the first submarine cable of 1850 to the worldwide fiber optic network, accessed August 1, 2013, http://atlantic-cable.com/Cables/CableTimeLine/index1850.htm.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: From a nearly dead-stop traffic jam, you escape Phnom Penh and start down the road to Sihanoukville. Once dubbed the most dangerous road in Cambodia, National Highway 4 was constructed to connect the capital to the country’s only international sea port. Trucks piled with containers, themselves loaded with merchandise to be shipped abroad, speed down the two-lane highway in all conditions, veering into oncoming traffic to pass. Along the roadside are innumerable sweatshops guarded by twelve-foot walls, places where the handbags, socks, and garments of all kinds are manufactured. Small towns have sprung up around them, along with markets that sell the national beer and display advertisements for the Cambodian People’s Party. Water and sewage transit next to the roadside. The cables planned to connect the country, which as of 2014 still had no undersea links, will follow the path of the road. Like the infrastructures before it, they will accelerate the region’s economic development, for better or for worse.

This Korean city has long been a hub for Japanese connections. In the nineteenth century it was the primary access point for Japanese merchants to Asian trade networks. When it opened, Pusan’s Japanese-run telegraph station became an equally important gateway. It handled all Korean telegraph traffic until an overland link to Seoul was completed in 1888, and it allowed Japanese-language telegrams to leave the country for the first time. Cable traffic spiked from a few thousand messages sent between the two countries in 1884 to some 430,000 — the vast majority were in Japanese. In 1931, Pusan was the site of Japanese experiments for another communications revolution: the use of undersea cables for voice transmission.

Known as the “River City,” Banjarmasin (once spelled Bandjermasin) is situated at the intersection of the Martapura and Barito rivers on Borneo’s southern coast. In the seventeenth century, the country’s rich natural resources—including gold, pepper, and gambier (a plant with medicinal properties)—were transported by river and sold in the natural harbor to Chinese, British, and Dutch traders. Native craftsmen were famous for their flat-bottomed wooden vessels, which carried goods through the city’s network of canals. After they secured a trade monopoly, the Dutch made Banjarmasin the capital of Borneo in the late 1700s. Soon thereafter, the electrical flows of telegraph communication joined the liquid and trade flows that defined the city’s pre-colonial history.
