http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: Waves crash up against a thick seawall that spans the coast of Toucheng. Much of the shore here in northeast Taiwan is comprised of sand rock, eroded by ocean waves and monsoon winds. Spectacular surface formations are cut into the sedimentary rock, some locals observe that these even resemble tofu. Yet the erosion here is not entirely natural. The presence of manmade structures on 56% of Taiwan’s coast, this seawall included, has sped up the disappearance of the coast. These structures interrupt the flow of sand, causing it to accumulate on one side and to quickly erode on the other. The nearby Toucheng beach, which once stretched for two kilometers, is now severely diminished, and the coast has retreated up to 100 meters inland. This seawall keeps the shoreline intact for both waves and cable stations, but provides an additional challenge for cable laying. Companies have to bore a hole through the thick walls in order to thread their networks through.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: When they set up their cable station in Cromer, Australia, the PIPE International team decided to take a new approach to dealing with the surrounding public. Instead of hiding the network’s development, they started a blog where they posted photos of the cable’s installation, the equipment they used, and the operators’ activities. One engineer recounts that they tried to do community outreach as well. At one point they hosted a barbeque and asked residents to come see why the company had occupied their park for several months. As he described: “a lot of PR went into it to make sure the objections and problems were minimized.” Instead, they made the cable laying “a social event.” PIPE’s efforts have paid off. Not only did their outreach efforts generate publicity for their network, but they have had few problems with the local community since they began operation.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/rightsHolder.value: Pipe Networks

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: In 1893, during an autumn stay in Hawai’i, Robert Louis Stevenson wrote an advertisement for the local news paper: “If anyone desire such old-fashioned things as lovely scenery, quiet, pure air, clear sea water, good food, and heavenly sunsets hung out before his eyes over the Pacific and the distant hills of Waianae, I recommend him cordially to the ‘Sans Souci.’” A decade later, much had changed: the Hawaiian islands had been annexed by the United States and a telegraph cable was strung ashore at Sans Souci beach, connecting Hawai’i to Midway Island. With the completion of this link, President Teddy Roosevelt sent a round-the-world telegram congratulating the cable’s projector, Mackay, from his home on Long Island to New York City via the Commerical Pacific Cable’s transoceanic link. The message took only twelve minutes. Little remains of this history at Sans Souci today, the only indication of the cable is a brief mention at the bottom of the menu of a local restaurant.

The island of Iki, along with its neighbor Tsushima, “form the stepping-stones between Japan and Korea,” explains a 1912 reference book. For centuries, Iki was an intermediate safe harbor for merchant and pirate ships passing through the Genkai Sea. And in the early 1900s, the island became a stepping-stone for cables. By 1920, seven telegraph cables had landed near the southwestern port town of Gōnoura, which sits at the base of an inactive volcano and is surrounded by rice fields. Four of these lines ran to the main Japanese islands and three to Tsushima, where additional cables carried messages the rest of the way to Busan. When a telephone line was installed in 1937, Iki became a stepping-stone for voice signals on their journey across the Korean Strait.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/bibliographicCi.value:
U.S. Hydrographic Office, Asiatic Pilot Volume II: The Japan Islands. Washington: Government Printing Office, 1910.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: A 1903 guidebook describes the bay of Kwandang as “beautiful and picturesque” but also “abandoned” and “densely covered with vegetation.” There is “scarcely a house or sign of cultivation . . . to be seen anywhere in the midst of the primeval wood.” The town is located inland from the port and is largely invisible through the foliage. Although secluded, “the neatness of the roads and houses proves that Kwandang is not a self-governed country, but under Dutch Government.” The Portuguese arrived in the 1500s and built a stone fort to defend the region from pirates. A century later, the Dutch took possession of the island-filled bay, one of the best natural harbors in northern Sulawesi. In 1903, they linked it by submarine cable to Balikpapan and Menado. Despite clear signs of development, however, Kwandang remained a wild place. A gang of pirates besieged the colony in the late 1800s until Dutch ships finally “came to the rescue from Ternate.”

http://purl.org/dc/terms/bibliographicCi.value:

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: The town of Koror in the Palau archipelago was once known as “Little Tokyo,” a nod to the strong Japanese presence on the islands between the First and Second World Wars. Palau’s strategic position in the North Pacific drew competing territorial claims from Britain, Spain, and Germany in the late 1800s. After a period of Spanish rule, the fertile islands were sold to the Germans who began exploiting their natural resources. Japan annexed Palau in 1914, established a regional government headquarters, promoted large-scale immigration, and built fish canneries and coconut processing plants. During World War II, a German telegraph cable was redirected to Palau to strengthen communication links to Japan. And in 1944, Japanese and U.S. forces clashed in the months-long Battle of Peleliu (an island in southeastern Palau) with heavy casualties on both sides.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/bibliographicCi.value: Gordon L. Rottman, World War II Pacific Island Guide: A Geo-Military Study. Westport, CT: Greenwood Press, 2002.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: In 1991, North Pacific Cable built a brand new station on the remote Oregon coast. Established far from the AT&T landing in Bandon, this building pioneered cable landing in northern Oregon, now a critical stopping point for Internet entering and leaving the country. Even though it paved the way for development, North Pacific Cable was eventually made obsolete by these newer links, and with this, the station was shut down. It was not until years afterward that Tillamook Lightwave purchased the station in order to help provide regional access to the network. Part of the station was leased to the University of Washington for their "Regional Scale Nodes" project, an ocean cable system that enables scientists to observe deep sea life forms and processes. A building constructed merely to funnel signals through the area now links the many populations, human and non-human, on the Oregon coast.

When it opened in 1991, the North Pacific Cable was the highest-capacity system to link Japan and North America. “This pioneering effort helps usher in what futurists . . . call the fibersphere,” declared the president of Pacific Telecom, the cable’s U.S. sponsor. The following year, Tokyo Broadcasting System sent high-definition television signals between Miura and Pacific City to demonstrate the “Advantages of terrestrial fiber transmission” over satellite, including “high bandwidth, high reliability and less delay.”

For a relatively brief period between 1980 and 1997, you could travel here from Pusan along a coaxial cable under the Korea Strait. Emerging on a white-sand beach, you’d find one of the largest deep-sea trade ports in western Japan, abuzz with ships carrying local fish, seaweed, and wood products. The town formed around a hilltop castle built in 1620 and later destroyed by its creators to prevent it from falling into enemy hands. Hamada’s cable station was also abandoned and dismantled, but for a different reason: new fiber-optic networks offered faster connections between Japan and Korea via hubs closer to Tokyo-Yokohama. While the castle ruins, including a stone foundation and wooden gateway, are now a popular tourist attraction that reminds visitors of the city’s long history, evidence of its place in the underwater network has all but disappeared.
Completed in 1980 by Japan’s KDDI Corporation, this coaxial cable linked Hamada and Pusan. It was decommissioned in 1997 and donated to the Ocean Research Institute at Tokyo University.

Marco Polo stopped at the remote islands of Poulo Condor (now known as Con Dao) on his way from China to India, later writing “there is nothing about them worth mentioning.” Yet the archipelago’s remoteness and nondescript character made it an ideal setting for more than a century of incarceration. After taking control of Poulo Condor in 1787, the French constructed a 120-cell prison to hold opponents of the colonial government, including many high-ranking Vietnamese military leaders. While prisoners were detained, French signals flowed freely through the island’s telegraph station. The prison was later turned over to the South Vietnamese and became the site of the notorious “tiger cages,” maintained by the U.S. during the Vietnam War. This isolated island became globally visible when a 1970 issue of Life magazine revealed the prison’s inhumane conditions.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/bibliographicCi.value:

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: The volcanic island of Jeju, meaning “province across the sea,” sits sixty miles off the coast of South Korea. Before the island became more closely linked to the mainland by tourism and underwater cables, it had a distinct language, culture, and ocean-based economy. Female free divers known as “haenyeo,” or “sea women,” have gathered shellfish and other marine life from the Korea Strait for generations, though their numbers are dwindling. In the 1990s, Jeju became a landing site for submarine electrical and communication lines. A branch of the Hong Kong-Japan-Korea (HJK) system surfaced in 1990, and in 1996, a high-voltage direct current cable joined the island’s power grid to the Korean Peninsula. With the decommissioning of HJK, Jeju fell out of the international cable circuit, redirecting all signal traffic through mainland hubs.
The Indian Ocean Commonwealth Cable was initiated in 1981.

No international communications cables land in Baltimore, but this maritime city is a hub of international cabling. TE Subcom – a company that manufactures, lays, and repairs a significant portion of the world’s undersea cables  – is based here. Giant cable ships are docked next to their harbor-side warehouse. Spools of cable remain nestled below deck. These ships can lay cable across an entire ocean, retrieve a line from the bottom of the seabed, and repair systems in mid-ocean. Given how complex and expensive they are, cableships are far and few between, making the cable repair industry reliant on companies such as TE Subcom.
